												Okay.. uhh.. wow.What to say about this game..It's definitely not something I thought it was going to be. I originally bought this game for the lolz since the general idea for this game is "Oh it's a dating sim... for birds.. lol" So originally, I played it as such. But as I carried on through the different routes you could take, I found each story more and more compelling. So many twists and turns and things that just randomly straight up hit you in the feels or made you think "wtf just happened?"The main story is really creative and the genre twist really takes you through a loop and keeps you hooked. And for birds, the characters are really well developed. I think the makers of this game knew exactly what they were doing. I want to take the player into a false sense of "This is going to be hilarious and stupid" Which granted, at some points, that's what it does. Very well. It's really funny.When really it's building you up for a huge unexpected story hit. All the different routes are just branches of character developments, readying you for the main plot. I applaud that. Over all, I'd actually recommend buying this game and doing exactly what everyone else is doing. Go in while not taking this game seriously at all and let it change your mind. Because it seriously will. Then it'll leave you there to sit there and think about how unexpectedly brilliantly done it is. Mediatonic, Hato Moa... hats off to you, this was a great experience.

												What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a bird dating sim.I purchased this because I thought it would be funny to say that I was playing a bird dating sim.  There wasn’t suppose to be any real feelings behind this purchase, it was all in jest.  I launched the game and quickly got to the bad ending.  I figured I should at least complete one or two “good” endings before I uninstalled the game and abandoned it to be just another game in my library.  To accomplish my goal of being able to complete a good ending, I quickly made a “birds.txt” where I would list everybody in the story with a couple words to allow me to remember who was who.Ryouta : Childhood friend, sickSakuya : ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Yuuya : Works in infirmiry, upperclassmen, half brother of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, flirtNageki : Library silent dudeSan : RUN RUN RUN RUN RUNKazuaki : Homeroom / math teacher, falls asleepShuu : DoctorReferencing this “cheat sheet”, I was able to get a good ending fairly easily.  I repeated myself, this time going for a different ending...sometime in this third playthrough, something changed.By the end of that ending, I was actually enjoying what I was doing.  This “Joke of a game” was actually drawing me in, not because of “bird dating sim”, but because of the actual plot and the compelling characters.  My cheat sheet was pointless, I knew all the names.  Everybirdie had their own personality, and their stories had wildly different outcomes, yet were all tied together to help reveal a plot that actually mattered. As you play through the game more, and achieve different endings you find little bits and pieces about the world.  You read how birds became the dominant lifeform on the planet, how the human race almost fell to extinction, and how bird politics work.Each story feel completely different.  They all showcase a huge variety of emotions and social conditions.  One story / ending exists entirely for humor, and no deep thought is put into anything.  You are able to laugh your way through a 20 minute story and have a great time.  You re-roll your game, and suddenly your story is filled with great sorrow between all the funny bird puns.  Sadness then turns into happiness as your story becomes complete.  Re-roll again, now you are exploring yet more bird puns, but this time also the impossible expectations sometimes forced onto oneself from their family.  Re-roll, now genocide is brought into the fold.  Re-roll, we are happy and excited again.What the hell just happened?  This game somehow managed to put an actual fantastic plot full of emotion and lessons of how the world works into...a bird dating simulator.  Somehow this completely over the top game idea is completely overlooked the more you play it and fall in love with it.Everybirdie should download this game and try it out because “lol bird dating sim”.  You’ll be amazed as the joke suddenly starts being enjoyable and the fact that everyone is a bird spouting bird puns is able to be completely overlooked.What is Hatoful Boyfriend? Hatoful Boyfriend is a fantastic game filled with more emotion and story than it should possibly contain.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Hatoful Boyfriend is more nuanced and compelling than it has any right to be.Its outrageous concept is so over the top that it’s hard to view the game as anything more than a joke; something amusing but mostly held together by the mere fact of its existence. But these preconceptions, strung along by even its own marketing and description, are hiding the shockingly well written and emotionally stirring narrative underneath.To be entirely clear, it is in part exactly what it appears to be: an otome dating simulator/visual novel, set in a world where birds have evolved to be the most intelligent species and humans have been mostly driven to extinction. Playing as the lone human student at Pigeonation Academy, you are tasked with going about your day, trying to scrape by in your schoolwork while wooing the bird of your dreams.It’s an intentionally laughable idea, and one which at first can seem so ridiculous as to turn those less drawn to Japan’s stranger exports away, but its one which never dissolves into idiotic bird lover pandering (assuming that’s a thing that exists) or outright stupidity with its writing. Hatoful Boyfriend is entirely aware of its own absurdity, and treats it almost as an afterthought, to the point that the fact these characters are nearly entirely birds became irrelevant at least as far as being a very odd novelty.Hatoful Boyfriend’s writing is exceptional, both hilarious and comical, and heart wrenchingly sad and contemplative. Though it begins as little more than a silly teenage romance, it spends this time crafting characters that you come to care about, before hurling them into a plot darker and more precarious than I ever could have imagine. While there are certainly parts (and entire storylines) within the game which are nothing but comedy, allowing the humorous and charming side of the game to take the spotlight for a moment and provide more than a few laughs, it was when the subject matter moved away from this silliness that I began to finally see the hidden brilliance of the game’s writer.It’s shocking to even consider at first, and even now as I’m writing this I’m rather stunned at what Hatoful Boyfriend manages to do with its narrative, but it handles it's incredibly dark material with incredible grace and consideration. Calculated genocide, mass murder and biological experimentation, interspecies racism, and the value of family are not only touched upon, but discussed at length and in such a way as to not only allow you to take them seriously within the game’s context, but actually emphasize and become emotionally invested in the avian characters that once seemed so innocent and comical.Hatoful Boyfriend made me laugh; it made me smile and appreciate its subtlety; and it made me cry. The spectrum of emotions I experienced throughout my handful of playthroughs (which should be considered a requisite, as you will miss the vast majority of the game’s content if you only go through it once) was something I never imagined this game to be capable of. It kept me playing for hours on end, up late into the night, and I’m still attempting to process all that I witnessed. It could very well be the apotheosis of a game you shouldn’t judge by its cover, and something that everybirdie ought to at least give a chance before writing it off as something it by and large is anything but.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												this game is an emotional trap. you buy it because the idea of a dating simulator with pigeons is 'LOL SO RANDOM!!11 XD' and full of 'teh lulz', but then you accidentally end up playing a parody game that turns out to be far better than the majority of material it's actually imitating.the writing is thoughtful and well-balanced, containing humor of the rare 'actually funny' type, which will result in feelings of warm attachment to the characters... before TWISTING THE KNIFE OF FEELINGS DEEPLY as a tragedy of Shakespearean proportions overwhelms the plotline arc and cast.the writing also has a highly surprising amount of depth, as the characters (including your own) must make some morally ambiguous choices, and even the most immoral characters have a few redeeming, wholly human features to their personalities which make them relatable and strangely likable.there are 16 different endings to the story that are achieved based on the choices you make, with one 'true ending' and 15 'alternate endings'; notably, the alternate endings to this story are cleverly interwoven into the 'true' ending plotline, as with each new ending you discover, you are given new revelations that consistently give you deeper insight into the events that unfold prior to the finale of the 'true' plotline. this means that there is an actual reader's value that goes beyond shallow 'what if' ideas to following every path to its ending, which is fairly uncommon in the genre of multiple-choice story games.the art is also clean, colorful and high quality, and the music sets the tone nicely. honestly the only thing i could wish for is that it was fully voiced (it isn't).recommended for people who actually enjoy good stories in visual novels, as opposed to the endless list of VNs with vapid, soulless storylines that rely on a cast of waifus and husbandos to appeal to buyers... although, you have been warned- after playing this game, the odds that you will have horrifyingly/ heartbreakingly fallen in love with your first ever 'pigeon husbando' are high...

												I share a similar story with many other reviewers here. I bought this game for the laughs. I mean, a pigeon dating sim? I assumed I'd have fun with it for a couple of hours and then be done. I was not expecting what happened next.  Cons I must admit that there are negatives, and I will point them out before I praise the game. To start off, I'm not sure if this can be considered a negative (I think it's a positive), but a few of the story lines seem to be created merely for amusement and humour. They make no sense, and are there as a joke. However, If you are looking for something that is 100% serious, you're in the wrong place, and I have absolutely no clue why you would be here in the first place. Anyway, the interface and skill point system is simple, but they do the job. There are a few spelling and grammar errors scattered throughout, which may be distracting, but they are far and few between. As well, the starting routes are short and perhaps shallow. I recommend you try to complete all of the endings in order to see the "Bad Boys Love" bonus ending and the epilogue.  Pros Despite all of that, this game sets you on an emotional roller coaster if you put in the time to explore the different routes, and carry through with the finale. With various endings, each path provides a unique narrative. If the final ending is achieved, all of the stories tie together quite well, leaving you with an unexpectedly profound story, a group of memorable characters, and a collection of bird puns. I came for the laughs. What I got was comedy, romance, horror, mystery, and tears.I didn't ask for this. But I'm glad it happened.

What does "Hatoful" even mean?...WARNING: CONTAINS POSSIBLE SPOILERS!!!Hatoful - hatofuru - is a word pun between the Japanese word hato - which means either dove, or pigeon - and the English adjectives of either Heartful or Hurtful. On these terms, the title of the game is self-explanatory. Hatoful Boyfriend is a humorous otome/visual novel in which you get to date birds. Aside the humorous, or even strikingly unconventional nature of the game, this joke veils a deeper truth.The story is set in the fictional future of 2188. A century ago starting with rock pigeons, birds all over the world started to take the next step in evolution and challenged the omnipotence of mankind. After a long period of conflict and even open war, the mankind survived only as a minority. Now, the majority of the world's conscient population consists of birds. In this particular dystopia, we take the role of the only human student invited to attend St. Pigeonation, the most prestigious high school for birds of the world.At first, the display of the story keeps us oblivious to the grim face of our setting. Nothing indicates that Hatoful Boyfriend would be more than an unimaginably crazy joke. We keep playing the game in this meaningless context, as a silly joke, flirting with different kinds of birds and all. We laugh our hearts out for the absurdity of given situations, the reactions and portrayals of characters, and logical flaws of the setting are unbearably funny. It is like watching one of the most absurd anime series, like ever!But as the stories progress, and we accomplish different kinds of romances, we learn a bit more about different characters each time. As we play, they become more than silly depictions of birds. We learn their stories, their backgrounds, their aspirations and their wounds... just like real people. I tell you, the narrative of this game, and the narrative's ability to conceal the most shocking fictional events in silly jokes are totally scary. As we play, bits and pieces roll up to their proper places to paint an incredibly political and ethical discussion with suspense and immense tragedy!Gameplay wise, nothing is extraordinary. There are some pretty background pictures, and an incredible amount of bird photos flying around. Each character has their own separate background music. You start reading, and make some dialogue or event choices now and then. Finally, it wraps up to become a romance path for a bird of your choice. When you complete all endings, and start a new game; you face with the question whether you'd like to keep a long forgotten promise. If you say yes, things take an incredible turn, to reveal all past mysteries. Annoying or peculiar occurrences that you've been witnessing in your prior games now form a painful meaning. This final storyline reveals a darker side to our fictional setting, and brings question to concepts such as war, peace, misinformation, discrimination, racial and ethnic differences, and even biological war! Now, that was certainly unexpected, wasn't it?Hatoful Boyfriend starts as an absurd joke for you to kill some meaningless time, yet if you bear with its lame display and take a moment to look deeper, it rewards you with a most thrilling and disturbingly realistic story. Take your time, get bored by the joke. You'll end up picking a glass of water to wash the bitter feeling in your throat towards the end.Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												When people hear the term "games as art" they generally make the mistake of lumping everything into the same visual category. Sometimes art is in the form of a concept or idea and not just an optical quality, and it's in this sense that I highly regard Hatoful Boyfriend as a work of art. It takes a tired and cliched concept and reworks it into a thought provoking and never before seen idea that manages to be both humorously satirical and affectingly sentimental, causing the general public to reconsider and ponder the meaning of a mostly mocked genre. Some may discount the games merits based on the corny puns, and these people miss the point entirely. What makes Hatoful Boyfriend so damn funny, so artfully clever, and so hard to stop smiling at is the overall concept of what's happening and the way the emotionally driven story is delivered. The idea of seeing such seriously toned dialogue combined with the strange and surreal imagery of a school of pigeons is wildly outside of the box, and to anyone with an imagination is at first incredibly entertaining. What really takes the player by surprise is the emotional draw the story has on you in the end for what at first was such a seemingly laughable and satirical plot.Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just a satire or a mockery, it's not just one big comedic joke like some might intially believe. The characters are written well and manage to shine with more personality and.. humanity(?) than what we're used to seeing in the generally shallow world of anime dating sims, which is what makes the experience feel even more bizarre, strange, yet memorable given it's subject matter. It manages to feel more real and authentic than even the most sensible or conventional games in this form of interactive storytelling.The strange feeling evoked by Hatoful Boyfriend of feeling a growing emotional attachment towards something so seemingly overlooked as a pigeon or bird in a video game is one I'll remember. People with no connection or empathy for the animal kingdom my find it hard to swallow the ongoings of St. Pigeonation and won't take away anything of value from this quirky change of pace needed in gaming, but those with an open mind and heart to the topic will come away with a new found respect and admiration for a species generally viewed as insignificant or often misunderstood.If you're the type who isn't too concerned with artistic and strange new takes on old genres, or you're one of those gamer types who enjoys the same-old-same-old while fearing changes to the industry then by all means skip this and play what you usually play. For people who want something new in the medium and want to see differences to gaming that allow a wider variety of people into the world of interactive experiences we call games then Hatoful Boyfriend is something you'll want to check out.

												Every once in a while, you run into something that challenges your expectations in ways you couldn’t have possibly expected. It wears the surface layer like a wolf in pigeon’s clothing, promising a few quick laughs through the trappings of a dolled up Visual Novel featuring an all-bird cast. And if you were to think of it as nothing more, what with all of the pink upholstery and hearts surrounding every element of the game’s outward presentation, then no one could blame you. But it also counts on this charade to drag the player into something beneath its skin. Hatoful Boyfriend is indeed a game about attending an all-bird high school as the only human in the academy. Yet, if one cares to look above, they’ll see a murder of crows circling overhead.Hatoful Boyfriend will appear familiar to anyone who has played a Visual Novel or two. Once you’ve started a new game, it will ask for your name, introduce you to the majority of characters in a warm and friendly environment, and generally settle you into daily life at St. PigeoNation. Navigation works similarly to the thousands which have come before it. You progress forward by clicking or hitting enter as a dialog box completes to display the next one and advance the story, occasionally make a selection to build your stats or guide which bird you will chase for their affection. There’s also the option to save and load, as well as alter some basic settings, and a convenient fast-forward button in the upper corner, should you wish to skip over dialog you’ve already seen. And of course, branching paths which all lead to their own endings, all depending on choices you make.The first trick Hatoful Boyfriend pulls out of its hat is how short a single run can last. The very first run I completed took me about an hour in total, which draws the player in, promising quick trips down alternative paths to collect all of the pigeon husbando~ hearts. This is exactly what it wants you to do. Only going through the game once wouldn’t allow for the seams in the feathered costume begin to show, so it pushes you towards seeking every han- er, wing, you possibly can. With every successful unique ending, you’re rewarded with curious snippets in the “archive” section in the main menu. Between the diary entries and newspaper clippings, it’s trying to warn you. Only, we’re too occupied as players staring at the plumes of tail feathers to see the forest for the trees.And it’s hard not to. The game’s use of standard visual novel/anime characterizations intelligently manipulates the player into wanting to chase down the Tsundere French transfer student, the plucky best friend you’ve known since you were both younger, the goth kid who speaks a language all his own, and even the creepy one who mutters statements under his breath that would be admissible evidence in court. Down each path, there’s plenty of humorous dialog and heart-tugging character development. The fact that they are all birds instead of humans or anime portraits just pulls the covers over your eyes when the real drama finally hits. They’re all entertainingly written, even if they stay extremely close to the tropes that birthed them. Let’s not allow the down comforter to be pulled over our eyes though. Several of the paths lean heavily into exposing Hatoful Boyfriend’s big secret, which is given to the player after certain endings have been cleared.BBL mode, known as “Bad Boys Love”, is what Hatoful Boyfriend is really building towards. All of the characters you meet, all of the interactions you have, they all lead down the path towards BBL mode’s story. To explain what exactly BBL is would be to spoil the true meat and potatoes of the game, and thus I can’t in good conscience actually explain it to you. Even if I did tell you, in great detail, what it is and what happens during it, there’s no way you’d actually believe me. It is a much bigger bird than the others, with secrets tucked between every feather. I’ve seen many reviews not even mention it in fear of spoiling it but I feel as though that isn’t enough to truly entice someone into playing the game. Much like Hatoful Boyfriend’s tricks, I have spent most of this review building up to BBL mode simply to get you interested in what lies beyond that cage door. In order for you to discover the truth, however, you’ll have to spread your wings on your own.It might just be because I let my guard down from the pigeon-centric cast but Hatoful Boyfriend left me feeling shaken. What I’d gone through was both hilarious and frightening at the same time. Just keep your wits about you, reinforce your constitution, and carve it into your soul. Hatoful Boyfriend is not just a dating sim where your boyfriends all have winged limbs and beaks. It’s an example of playing to the strengths and comforts of a genre while turning convention on its head to have the stork deliver a story so full of twists that it took me 3 sheets of paper and small handwriting to keep track of it all.Did you enjoy this review? If so, be sure to stop by at RGZ.CA to see all of my reviews, as well as the work of the other writers! http://rgz.ca/gaming/hatoful-boyfriend-review-this-bird-has-flown/

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I appear to be the first negative reviewer to have completed the game in its entirety.  This game has two distinct parts, the dating sim and the Bad Boys Love secret route unlocked by romancing every bird possible.The first part is simply too short to be entertaining.  Any route can be read in about an hour going at a relaxed pace, but there is significant overlap between routes, including sections that have no effect on the particular route you're playing, so I found myself skipping more and more as I replayed.  This also caused me to inadvertantly skip content I hadn't read before, because some sections have multiple outcomes but start out the same way regardless of route.  There is no way to go back to content accidentally skipped without reloading or starting a new game and it simply wasn't interesting enough to worth bothering to find out why I was faced with the choice of telling Okosan "convenience store" or "grocery store" and I could infer it had something to do with pudding anyway.Consequently, there just isn't enough time to give any character depth and there's no challenge to complete a route.  By the time you finish a route, you feel like you were merely introduced to the character.  Picking routes are also very obvious and there is never any difficulty in seducing the various birds, unless you can't figure out that picking every opportunity to spend time with your desired bird is necessary to romance them.  The routes I enjoyed most, Okosan, Shuu, and Anghel, stood out because they were simply the most oddball.  For a game that is billed as a comedy, most routes utilize stereotypical melodrama.  Bird puns and pop culture references abound, but there's really nothing laugh out loud funny in Hatoful Boyfriend and at best you'll smirk a lot.  There is a very simple stat system, raised by choosing between three elective classes at regular intervals and in a couple of events that likewise present three choices which raise a stat.  The stats serve one purpose, which is to determine whether you get a normal ending or an extended ending.  Extended endings require you to raise one stat to maximum and reward you with an extra scene that was implied in the normal ending anyway.  Each ending has a separate achievement and you can't get both the normal ending and extended ending achievements in one go, so you have to play the same route twice in order to get all the achievements and unlock the Bad Boys Love extended ending.  I wasted part of my life to get the BBL extended ending and it was just as disappointing as the other extended endings.The second part of the game, the Bad Boys Love secret route is much more interesting, but by the time I unlocked it I was already tired of the game.  I trudged on in hopes that it would be good and it was, kind of.  The game suddenly takes a much darker tone, reveals how the world came to be dominated by talking birds, and becomes a mystery story.  It seems interesting for a while, but as all the threads come together it becomes a soap opera for the ages.  Characters are revealed to be secret brothers, secret childhood friends, secret enemies, secret agents, secret terrorists, secret weapons, secretly superpowered, secretly alive, but, alas, there are no secret comas to complete the cliche pantheon.  I got the distinct impression that the first half of the game was written primarily to introduce the characters so that the meandering mysteries wouldn't simply baffle readers.All in all, Hatoful Boyfriend wasn't an altogether terrible game, but it just wasn't worth the money and I got it in a 50% off sale.  I will likely never read it again and would forget about it entirely if Steam didn't keep it in my library forever.  As some consolation, the trading cards were surprisingly valuable and I was able to quickly sell them for about $1.50.If you don't mind a lot of repetition, love every visual novel no matter what, and really love silly gimmicks, then buy this game.  Otherwise, pick up just about any other visual novel on Steam.  Even some of the free ones are more entertaining than Hatoful Boyfriend.4/10

												This game is not a satirical parody of visual novels in any way whatsoever, contrary to how it appears.Going into Hatoful Boyfriend you can't help but think "Damn, this is going to be one hell of a weird game" and although you're right in saying that, it's much, much more. Although it's hard to review this game without spoiling nearly everything I can truthfully tell you that it's well worth your time and that you'd be missing out if you passed Hatoful Boyfriend up.Despite each playthrough being short (around 45 minutes to an hour and a half per route) there are fourteen total endings, following the usual visual novel fashion of ranging from happy, lovely fairy tale-esque endings to extremely dark, likely traumatic endings. Things escalate QUICKLY. Eventually you'll reach the point where you can experience the true ending, which lasts a fair bit longer than usual and is actually an incredibly suspenseful and fascinating mystery/thriller. It alone is worth the price of admission.The characters, although they're well.. birds are actually fairly well designed albeit a little basic due to the short, concise nature of the game itself. Artistically the characters are beautifully drawn and are, admittedly, very good looking.The soundtrack is solid, fairly run-of-the-mill for the most part with a few tracks that really stand out.All in all, despite being mediocre as far as visual novel gameplay and writing goes, the game's charm makes it entirely worthwhile, and hey, who doesn't want to tell their friends that they've been playing a bird dating simulator?

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												If you like visual novels and/or dating sims, or are willing to try playing one of those, I cannot recommend this game enough.I know this sounds weird. Dating pigeons? This is obviously some kinda joke that has no right costing as much as it does.But I can guarantee that playing the old version of Hatoful Boyfriend back in 2012 was one of the best experiences in my life. I thought, "Hey, I like dating sims and the demo is free, the worst that can happen is that I'll hate it and delete it".No, the worst that could happen was getting my heart crushed into a million pieces and falling in love with a game about birds. I mean, I don't even like birds!But what this game really did was teach me that you can't judge a book (or a game) by its cover, that being open-minded and looking past your preconceptions is important, and that it's nice to try new things once in a while. You might be surprised by what you find.If you think the very concept of this game isn't reason enough to give it a try, I'm not sure what to say. Come back and try again later?This less-than-ten-bucks game that looked like nothing but a silly joke, with only one picture for every character, that used mostly free resources and stock images, managed to be so much more immersive and interesting than any other high-budget visual novel I've played.The game does play like a parody of dating sims for at least half of the game, but even then, the characters are very fleshed out and well written, so if you're looking for something nice to break away from the generic high school girls with the same old no-plot dating experience, this is it.If you're familiar with dating sims (or harem anime) you'll recognize the character types right away: you have the childhood friend, the teacher, the quiet one you're not sure how to approach, the ladies man, the spoiled one, and the list goes on. But there's a lot more to these characters than what you can see at first glance, and figuring out their stories and why's and how's is half the fun.There are many funny moments, yes, oh so many. Hatoful Boyfriend fully embraces its weird concept, which makes it very enjoyable and fun to play. It's not just the birds - the player character is also a very funny character with quite a few gems in her dialogue.But as you play you can easily notice there's so much more going on; there's always that hint of something deeper and darker on the back of every route. The game doesn't just take things for granted - most questions raised during the game will be answered. For example, why you're the only human in a school for birds. Yes, this is addressed in the game, and you might be quite surprised by the explanation.The storytelling in this game is incredibly well done. It's not just what's expected of a visual novel, but a step above.There's not much more I can say about it without getting into spoiler territory, so you'll just have to see for yourself.TL;DR: There's something for everyone in this game. If you're not afraid of new experiences, give it a try - you may be surprised by how easy it is to get absorbed into this game's odd, comical atmosphere. Once you're into it, you may want to go all the way in. The routes are short enough that you'll find the time to play more of them. If you don't like it, well, at least you can say you tried - brag to your friends about how you didn't survive the pigeon dating sim!

Posted: October 29, 2014
												I'd heard about Hatoful.  I'd laughed at the premise. "A DATING SIM ABOUT PIGEONS?! HA!"  I held out playing it for so long because it just seemed to hilarious to be true.  And then.... I downloaded the demo.  Let me tell you, at first, I was just, "Oh, this game is so cute!  Look at these adorable interactions!"  I completed the demo with Yuuya and was completely enamored.  I /needed/ the full version.  Enter Steam, releasing it in HD.Dear Puddi, I never expected this game to give me what I got.  There's so much going on that you cannot glean from just playing one or two routes.  Play the whole thing.  Then play the BBL route and cry a million tears.  Cute game, yeah right.  More like vicious emotionally destructive game.  And I don't regret buying it--I regret laughing at it and putting it off as some dumb game.  Why there isn't more light on Hatoful is beyond me, because it's a beautiful game.  Does it have its errors?  Of course, doesn't every game?  It's well put together, though, and any errors in the script don't detract from the game (they may make you read the segment a few times, but it's definitely not game-breaking).  I've played a dating sim or two in my time, but this one is probably the best.  These are well-written characters, with feathers, of course.  It's easy to develop a connection with them because they are so well-written with hidden histories and pasts that you can find in Moa's mangas (available on Amazon!).TL;DR: If you have any preconceptions about this game, FORGET THEM.  Buy it and try it for yourself.  Don't watch someone else play it, and don't just brush it off as some dumb game, because it's definitely worth the hours it takes to play it fully and completely.  Happy Birding ♥P.S.: If you buy Hatoful and you enjoy it and want to put yourself through additional pain and misery, there is a sequel called "Holiday Star," available in English (i.e.: you don't need to patch it) for about $3, if I remember right.  Just visit Moa's wordpress and you can get it!2016 Update:  I still love this game.  I still feel crushed every time I think about the true ending, and everytime I see an image of Shuu.  Definitely worth the money and time spent.

Posted: September 5, 2014
												Hatoful Boyfriend is a game where you go to bird school, which is for birds (and you, a human), and you date a bunch of different pigeons (or quails, or even a java sparrow) over a series of eight different routes. The game is relatively short in this aspect! I was surprised by how quickly I was getting through each route--even with fourteen endings to get (some sweet, some sad, some downright horrifying), the game itself feels surprisingly short.However, this is likely because completing specific routes unlocks the other "half" of the game, as such--a more straight-up visual novel that reveals the secrets behind St. PigeoNation's (the school that you attend) and exemplifies some pretty excellent worldbuilding for what, on the surface, appears to be a game about dating birds. It also delves further into the backgrounds of each of the main characters and will emotionally destroy you.The game has a few typos and questionably built sentences, but it's overall an enjoyable playing experience. The background art is pretty nice to look at and some of the music is so great I sort of regret not buying the collector's edition to get the soundtrack.10/10, would let pigeons emotionally destroy me again.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Most reviews promise something unique and they are right. There is a lot of enjoyable writing in this "game" but to me it is worth neither the time nor the money needed to uncover it.The setting is hilariously absurd and the graphics are quite minimalistic (hand drawn backgrounds with a total of about a dozen photos of birds for the foreground). I quickly got used to both. What really spoils the experience for me is the horrible interface. This game is basically a novel where you click through lots of dialogue. One would assume that it provides a pleasant interface for that. This is not so:- The save function does not work when facing a decision - a natural point to save - and the saves seem to be broken at times.- There is much overlap between subsequent playthroughs so it is very tempting to use the fast forward function. However, that function does not stop when encountering those scarsely scattered bits of new dialogue. Also there is no rewind function so more often than not you miss some content. Why can't I just jump back and forth however I like? Even novels on paper have that feature.- I really miss an overview of the characters with full name that is always accessible. The game uses first names or nicknames most of the time but occasionally a character is refered to by last name and you only ever see these in the initial introduction.- Two of the endings have absolutely obscure trigger conditions and it took me a guide to get them.Finally, be aware what you're getting for the price: After watching the trailer and looking at the screenshots on the store page and you have seen a good part of the visual content. Apart from that it is a couple of thousand lines of entertaining text in a flawed "engine".

Posted: February 26, 2015
												I, uh, I c-can explain! J-just give me a sec; it's not what it looks like! I got the game for t-the, um, story! Just listen, I'm going somewhere with this okay? *sigh* Okay, without further ado, I present to you...LASTING IMPRESSIONSHatoful BoyfriendGENREDating Simulator/Visual NovelSTORYIn Hatoful Boyfriend you take the role of Hiyoko Tosaka, a human going to a prestigious highschool for birds. The school in question is St. Pigeonation’s, and it's known mostly for being the world's greatest gathering place for birds. You're a sophomore now, but you haven't done much to adjust to the atmosphere of Pigeonation's just yet. You're not entirely lost though, as you also have one of the several woo-able birds with you, your hardworking best friend Ryouta Kawara. Along with him you can also bond with narcoleptic math teacher Nanaki Kazuaki, bashful aristocrat Sakuya Le Bel Shirogane, distant bookworm Fujishiro Nageki, suave ladies' man Sakazaki Yuuya, enigmatic doctor Iwamine Shuu, and hyperactive track star Okosan. With so much romance in the air, it's hard to believe the school holds so many dark secrets...GAMEPLAYEver read a book online? It's like that except every once in a while the books asks which choice you want to make. The choices you make will determine which bird you end up with, along with which ending you get for them. [Provided you don't get indesicive and go the way of the dodo, of course.] Each day you will be asked which class you want to take; this decides which trait will be leveled for that day. As previously mentioned, this will affect which ending you get for your desired bird.VISUALSNot much to say. It's pictures of birds with various backgrounds. The backgrounds look very nice, and there's quite a large amount of them. You also get a little end card pictures for your gallery after the end of each route. They're gosh darned cute.SOUNDTRACKThe soundtrack is a delightful mix of royalty-free, classics, and original [I think?] tracks. All of them fit perfectly with any of the situations at hand. [Except maybe when Dance of the Sugar Plum Fairy plays, that's always just plain silly.] There's many tracks from Kevin MacLoed and SENTIVE; the sexy, suave Dispersion Relation, Simply Blue, Daybreak [Personal favorite.], and tons of ones with gibberish for names. The collector's edition is worth is just for the beautiful OST.SEQUELS [SPOILERS]Hatoful Boyfriend is the quintessential example of an idea that I've had for a while now; some games should never get sequels. While it's obvious that a bad game shouldn't deserve a sequel; I'm of the opinion that if a game is GOOD enough it shouldn't HAVE a sequel. If a game does all that it wishes, if a game provides a fulfilling, complete experience; it would be insulting to continue where the game left off. You may be thinking 'How does a game about dating birds provide a fulfilling experience?' I'll tell you; it's because the entire dating sim portion of the game is a mere facade. Once you've completed all possible routes at least once, you have the option to unlock BBL; a grim narrative that reveals the lore behind this game's world, the motivations and sins of characters, and completes all story arcs. The dating sim part of Hatoful Boyfriend is there simply to set up characters so that you know who this story is centered around. You know how they act by then, what their situations are, and this only helps to greatly strengthen the story. It's a fantastic conclusion, and it's one that left me speechless. Which brings us back to sequels. As I've said, a sequel to this game woud be a downright insult; a direct sequel that is. A direct sequel would be insulting, as the game would have nowhere to go with the current story; all arcs are completed. However, an indirect sequel would be a very, very smart idea if done correctly. By merely taking the characters we know and love and putting them in a different kind of story; the game has somewhere to go. Oh, and it did go somwhere, as an indirect sequel exists. [Holiday Star is its name if you were wondering. Not yet on steam though.]FINAL THOUGHTSI dove this game. To say that this was a pheasant experience would be the understatement of the century. While at first glance, it may look like quite the bad egg, it's surely a narrative you'll never forget. I'm talon you, it's all here! Great soundtrack, amazing characters, bird puns; it's just a quail of a time! The price ain't nothin to go squawkin' about neither, no need to worry about some ludicrous bill. This is the defenition of the phrase 'more than meets the eye' and you'd have to be some hard boiled individual not to enjoy the humor at the least. I know I'm gushing, but I just can't recommend this enough! While you're at it, make sure to kill two birds with one stone and buy the collector's edition with it. The soundtrack alone makes it worth it. Alright, I've egged you on for far too much now, I'll sparrow you of any more. Hatoful Boyfriend has left a resounding lasting impression; it's not what the source material is, it's what you do with it that makes it a golden goose egg. You've got your ducks in a row MediaTonic, keep it up.And now, in Japanese tradition, a haiku.Hatoful Boyfriend,A dating sim about birds.I was not prepared.

Posted: September 8, 2014
												In Hatoful Boyfriend, you play as Hiyoko Tosaka (or whatever you choose to name her), the only human in a school of pigeons. You can even get yourself a birdy boyfriend! There's Ryouta the childhood friend, Sakuya the fancypants, Yuuya the ladies man, and many more amazing avians. It plays out like a regular otome/visual novel does, read the text and make some choices. I bet you're thinking "omg so random, dating pigeons lol", and that's a natural response. But if you were to look up the definition of "don't judge a book by its cover", I'm pretty sure there would be a picture of Hatoful Boyfriend there.You see, the pigeon dating sim premise is just a cover for the real story. After you unlock certain endings with different birds, you can start a new game and the true story will reveal itself, aka the Hurtful Boyfriend (or Bad Boys Love) route. In BBL you will learn why Hiyoko is the only human at the pigeon school, why the pigeons can talk, why she needs to form a bond with the birds, and much more. I can only say so much without spoiling it, but be prepared for a mental meltdown. It is filled with drama, tragedy and unsettling content. After seeing certain endings in the dating sim part, you'll probably be thinking "well, I've already seen some disturbing stuff... This will be a piece of cake". LOL NOPE. The dating sim endings are nothing compared to the true BBL route. To put it simply, this game is like one of those sweet & sour candies; it looks and tastes sweet on the outside, but once you delve deeper in you'll reel back in shock and wonder wtf happened to the sugary outer shell.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												One of my favorite games!  Or rather, one of my favorite stories.  This is a visual novel and real, game-changing choices are limited: you will follow the tracks you pick like a choose-you-own-adventure book, with fairly limited endings.  It's a great "book" though, and one I encourge you to read through!It helps if you've played at least one "traditional" dating sim (or watched a harem anime) before.  I think it might be more enjoyable if you know the tropes and character archtypes that are being played with here.The "true" ending of the game is unlockable after completing romantic routes with the main dateable cast.  I try not to talk about it with those who haven't played the game because it really is best to go into it unspoiled.  It is a very intense story that will answer some questions about the setting.  The main game plays with no worldbuilding, assuming you (as the character) have lived in the world your whole life and do not need the history of the bird world explained.  The true end (titled "Hurtful Boyfriend" or "BBL") opens up and tells you (as the player) what's really going on.  The whole truth, however, you'll need to discover for yourself, as information is given piece by suspensful piece as you realize how the characters are connected in a complex web that you probably won't expect.I bought the original version of this game a few years before the steam release, at the recommendation of a friend who LUVED it.  I only played a few routes on that version, but I liked it enough to purchase the updated version for sale here on steam.  The steam release is an updated version of the original game with newly drawn graphics, higher quality pigeon pictures, and most importantly a smoother, easier to read text box.  This version also includes a new side route to romance Azami.  I think it says something that I happily bought this game twice.Then, if you like the game and want more of this story, check out the sequel (Holiday Star), the manga side stories, and the drama CDS.  None of which are essential to enjoying the game, but are also very enjoyable in their own right!

This isn't played for laughs in the writing, even during the normal routes.There's no "good end bad end" endings but "non-canon" endings where, quite simply, you survive and successfully romance a bird (Except a few endings but you'll find those if you play).The BBL (Bad Boys Love): Hurtful Boyfriend ending unlocks when you've received all fourteen endings. BBL tells the canon story of the Hatoful world, explaining WHY you, Hiyoko Tosaka, are a human coexisting with highly evolved birds.It's a long convoluted story, taking approximately four hours to complete. The BBL ending plays like a normal route until about halfway through the school year, when Hiyoko is murdered.Sh*t hits the fan, and you don't have choices like a normal route. The game turns into a visual novel, only requiring you to click along to continue the dialogue and reveal the story.I think Hatoful's only real flaw (besides some typos, notably in Nageki's BBL ending) is the monotony if you're trying to unlock all the endings at once. Luckily there's a fast forward button.This is a good story. The Planet of the Apes scenario works well, and you become less concerned that this school is for birds, and more interested in the characters and why things have been a little weird this whole time. It takes dating game tropes and turns them into its own.Hatoful completely flips the direction of typical dating games, to tell a good story, and remains self-aware the whole time.I really like this game and encourage people who enjoy strong writing to play it. 10/10. Would attend birb school again.

												Do you like dating sims? No? Yes?Well, that doesn't matter, because "Hatoful Boyfriend" is hilarious, and deserves a playthrough either way.I know there's tons of reviews for this game already, so there's not much else I can say that everyone hasn't said before, but what I can say is that I walked in blind, and it ended up being one of my favorite games. Still, there's something for everyone, with some of the routes becoming surprisingy poignant.The translation, despite a few typos, is delightful, and the writing was very clearly done with love. Even if the art is quite literally stock photos of birds, don't let that dissaude you: It's actually a very well-made game.The special route, the "Bad Boys' Love" Route, also deserves a mention, as it elevates the game from "fun gimmick" to "wow this is actually really well-done".And for those who want more of the fun (and pain), the Christmas sequel, "Holiday Star", is a nice addition to the franchise. All in all, while I'd wait to get this game on sale in a combo pack with the sequel and some bonus material, it's worth a playthrough no matter what.It's birdy-ful.

Posted: February 19, 2015
												Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel about birds. It is actually a parody of visual novels, with the classic character archetypes you'd expect in a school setting in an anime/visual novel: the childhood friend, the snob rich guy, the athletic guy...What differentiates it from other visual novels is, of course, the fact that these characters are all birds. That makes many normal situations inherently hilarious. However, do not dismiss it as just a comedy game. Beneath all the "haha, birds" is a strangely compelling and engrossing story. There's a surprising attention to detail, from the random bird facts it throws out sometimes to the well-thought-out world full of interesting characters.I have few complaints about the game, but the main one would be the lack of an "auto-skip only seen text" option. To get all the endings you need to replay the game multiple times, which is immensely helped by the auto-skip button. However, the auto-skip will also happily skip over unseen content if you let it be. That can lead to missing certain scenes.Still, I really like this game. It was far, far better than what I expected and is probably one of the best visual novels I have ever played. I also hate it. Because now nobody will believe me when I say that a game about birds is so good.

Posted: September 7, 2014
												Let's be honest: we all buy Hatoful Boyfriend for the sheer absurdity of what is, at its core, a visual novel pigeon dating game. And, on its surface at least, Hatoful Boyfriend is a shallow dating sim where the human main character is enrolled at St. PigeoNation's, a school for pigeons. She takes classes, she goes to festivals, and she romances and falls in love with various species of birds. However, Hatoful Boyfriend's stereotypical high school romance exterior is only an entertaining and light-hearted charade that covers up a plot full of politics, intrigue, mystery, and sorrow.The first half of Hatoful Boyfriend is quirky and humorous, filled with various pop culture jokes and absurd situations. Players find themselves romancing one of several standard character archetypes: the childhood best friend, the lazy professor, the haughty aristocrat, the womanizing jock, the bullied library nerd, and so on. The scenarios are cute and heart-warming, with each character having their own separate little storyline. Every short playthrough of the game—which frequently take under an hour even if you read all of the text—ends with a primarily sappy romantic ending.As players go through multiple playthroughs of Hatoful Boyfriend, however, a more insidious underlying plot is slowly revealed. Every romantic plot line will unveil more pieces of St. PigeoNation's dark history and the tragic cast of characters that attend classes there. These pieces on their own add spice to an otherwise bland dating sim that seems to cash in on its unique and somewhat ridiculous premise of a human girl dating pigeons. And, if one were to stop playing Hatoful Boyfriend after only a couple of playthroughs, that would be the feeling that one would be left with: Hatoful Boyfriend is an amusing dating game to spend an afternoon on, but nothing remarkable.However, players that choose to stop playing Hatoful Boyfriend after only a few short playthroughs are missing out on the part of Hatoful Boyfriend that makes it an excellent game. If the first thirteen playthroughs of Hatoful Boyfriend are an amusing way to pass an afternoon, then the last playthrough is a gut-wrenching ride through a twisting plot that ties together everything the player has done up to that point. The short of it is this: this isn't just a game that you should play, it's a game that you should strive to complete 100% of the way.

Posted: February 5, 2015
												This game isn't entirely bad, but I don't think it's worth the money.On the plus side:The game is unique.The secret ending that you can unlock is fairly interesting.On the minus side:The writing, especially for the non-secret parts of the game, is quite poor and does little or nothing to attach you to the characters, and the jokes are rarely funny. The decisions you get to make are not all that interesting.Only a minority of the text is different between the various non-secret paths. The majority is exactly the same, so you end up seeing the same text repeatedly.The UI lacks the features one would expect from a game in this genre, and generally seems a bit shoddy. You can't save at decision points. There's no way to easily skip over the text you've already seen to get to the new stuff, which is especially egregious given how much duplication there is between paths. (You can fast-forward, but it skips right over the new text too.) And there's no way to review the dialogue if you accidentally miss a line.There are some bugs. At one point, the game became unresponsive to input and I had to kill it, losing my progress since the last save. At another point, my saved game became corrupted and I had to start over. These were rare enough that they weren't really a problem, but they happened. Just save sometimes and use more than one slot.The secret path - which is really the only reason to get this game - has effectively no interactivity. It's just an exercise in tapping the space bar and reading text for an hour. That said, it's at least fairly interesting text.The non-secret paths are short and the game as a whole will probably take about 7-10 hours if you have the patience to go through it all.As somebody else said, it seems like the whole rest of the game is just a setup for the secret ending. It was something of a slog to get to that secret ending, but I did enjoy it once I got there. But I can't recommend this game at full price. You're basically paying for several hours of banal "play" in order to get the reward of reading a non-interactive but fairly interesting short story. For the money you can buy much better full-length books, and there are plenty of fascinating short stories to read online for free. But if you really want to read a short story about anthropomorphic pigeons, Hatoful Boyfriend might be for you.

And if you don't think you're up to it, you haven't played this masterpiece yet. This isn't just a game. It's a journey. A life-changing experience. Prepare to have your eyes opened to the truth.Hatoful Boyfriend actually falls under the category of visual novel, as it's a Japanese otome game. Otome is Japanese for sausage fest. You're playing a girl getting aggressively humped by every guy in the immediate vicinity. Which, in this case, are all birds. And you get to make the exciting choices that will determine not only who's eggs you'll be laying, but the fate of the world as we know it.Hatoful Boyfriend was originally developed for the PC in 2011, later seeing multiple rereleases and upgrades before getting an HD remaster that released on Steam, PS4, and PS Vita.Hatoful Boyfriend is, simply by existing, worth checking out. No where else can you experience the excitement of being the only human girl at an all-birds high school. It's the only of its kind, and simply the premise itself should warrant at least a single playthrough.Not only is it relevant simply because of its premise, but it also works rather well simply on its premise alone. If you're picking it up simply because "LOOK, BIRDS" you'll get exactly what you're looking for. It's wacky, zany, kooky bird fun. Good stuff.But underneath that simple premise, a surprising amount of depth is layered. Spoiler alert, dating birds at an all-birds school is not something people usually do. Usually. It's not quite a mainstream way of life yet, but we're rallying for our lifestyle to be recognized by the masses. Someday, human-bird relationships might be accepted. Birds don't even have access to public schooling yet, so we have a ways to go.Shockingly, Hatoful Boyfriend is a parody dating sim. A joke game of sorts, satirizing the otome genre. All of the cliches, all of the character stereotypes, they're all here. You can expect all of basics to be here. Maid costumes and all. It's tasteful satire, not in an overbearing "LOOK GUYS WE'RE MAKING JOKES HERE" kind of way. The writing is hilarious, and carries a sort of ironic whimsy to it. It's fully aware of its nature, but runs with it regardless. It is a visual novel, which means reading, which means no this is not an action game or anything vigorous like that. Unless you wanna dip your little parakeet perch in honey and bird seed so you can stick it through the bars of grandma's lovebird cage while you play. Those HD character portraits are pretty feathery.It's not only poking fun at otome visual novels, it's in fact written well enough to be a competent example of the genre that it's making a mockery of. The characters are interesting and compelling in their own right, even if they are just caricatures of otome stereotypes given bird form. They're fleshed out with a surprising amount of detail, given that the nature of the game didn't require much to begin with. Just "look, they're birds that you can date, this one is the jock bird and this one is the nerd bird" would have sold just as well. If you happen to fall in love with the excellently written birds and words, a lot is in store for you. They've done a beyond fantastic job of rewarding the player for dedication. As a dating sim should, there are multiple endings. At least one for each character, and sometimes two. One "true ending" should you flawlessly woo them, and the just okay ending. Where you confess your love and they say "thanks". Going the extra mile for more endings will reward you by unlocking even more endings. Better endings.And should you stick around long enough for every single ending, you will be generously rewarded with the best part of the game. There's a lot of tough choices to make, but if you make them all it will be so worth it.Fantastic writing, characters, atmosphere, and a stunning amount of depth and meaning really make Hatoful stand out among other visual novel games. But it's not without issues, though they're more to blame of the genre itself than anything else.After you've played through the game for the first time, regardless of which bird you hope to woo, much of the game remains the same. You'll be going to the same classes, seeing a lot of similar dialogue, and riding the fast-forward text button a ton. That's the biggest flaw with the game.The other being, as I mentioned, the game rewarding people that stick through the game until the very end. Because it's a really big reward. Like, possibly the size of the rest of the game itself in its entirety. I can totally understand why they did it, because the reward itself doesn't carry quite the same impact and meaning until you've played through every ending. It's a steep hill to climb, with a pay-off to match.To go any further would spoil just how perfect the ending is, but it stays true to its absurdity all the way to the end. It honestly blew me away how much depth they put into it. It's really not a one-trick pigeon, as it might lead you to believe.People might dismiss it as "that weird bird game" or "creepy Japanese♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; or "memes". They might play it purely for the "look at me lol I'm so random" factor, or the jack off to those luscious, feathery bodies. But you realize you're dismissing, stereotyping, and fetishizing a way of life. There's more to it than that. There's depth here. We're more than a stereotype, and I'm tired of needing to hide who I am.Educate yourself, open your mind, and accept that some people have a different lifestyle than you. Some people want to have a nice family with kids in a suburban house. They want that white picket fence life. And some people, they really like birds. Not that there's anything wrong with that. And if you think there is, I think you need to check your privilege. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

content:
Posted: January 16
Hatoful BoyfriendA game by birds, for birds, of birds.  What can I even begin to say about this game? What can anyone say about this game? Is this even a game? I can't really tell much anymore.  So, if it isn't blatantly obvious by the big blue thumbs-up right over there to the left a little bit, I like this game. A lot. In fact, it has surpassed, to me, the likes of Undertale, Borderlands, and my previous favourite game in existence (Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Sky, which I would absolutely recommend you try via emulator if you haven't played it already), to reign supreme above them all.Why?Well, I'm glad you asked. That's what this "Review" feature on Steam is for. It's a really handy little thing.TL;DR Review  So, first off, the short version for all of you who'd like to get a general consensus on my feelings about this game and why you should have bought it already, and then bought it for a friend or seven immediately afterwards, and for those who want to avoid knowing much about it. Trust me, you really do want to go into this game knowing as little as possible.  Hatoful Boyfriend is a dating simulation game about birds. Pigeons, to be exact. It has you play the only human girl in a school full of the things, and it's your job to get one of them to like you enough to have beautiful, mutated half-bird/half-human hybrid children a couple years down the line with.    Of course, you've got a wide selection to choose from. You have your typical tropes that can be found in most of these sort of visual novel-style games, such as the "best friend" character and the character who thinks they're above everyone else, but there's also some more varied personalities, including a creepy doctor and someone who thinks they live in a JRPG.  If you're a fan of these sorts of point-and-click narrative-driven experiences, then you'll adore Hatoful Boyfriend, as it both combines a legitimately enthralling narrative with a grand amount of humour, wit, and a tendency to subvert the tropes the genre is based on.   It plays great, it looks great, and if you find that you like the characters' personalities, which are the driving force of the experience, then there is not a doubt in my mind that you will find yourself having fun when going through, even if it's just for the first couple of routes you decide on. Which, by the way, there are a total of sixteen of spread out amongst the game. It's honestly pretty impressive.  Alright, now that that's out of the way, please play the game before reading any further. I'm dead serious. I do not spoil anything directly other than the personalities of each individual character and a couple other minor things, but I assure you that the experience is much better suited to play absolutely on your own. Go buy it right now, sit down, get a couple endings, and come back if you so choose.Or just ignore me and keep reading. Whatever's your cup of tea.The Actual ReviewTake this as a secondary line of caution even if you don't need one, but I cannot quite fit the full review on here. Instead, I've made a Google Document containing the rest of it.If you really want to slog through all of my detailed opinions, you can do so here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1O9psrhGKXXMgyj4W_GMLPY_5jq0LQl8koUbumt1PyM0Long story short, though, buy this game. Just do it.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												I was originally gifted this game in jest, and one day decided to further the joke by making this a 'perfect game' on my account. What's ironic is that without gunning for all the achievements on this, I would never have played Hatoful Boyfriend past the first one or two endings. Why? Well, the surface dating sim is fun enough - but unless you're using a guide or are very skilful with your save points, it can get tedious working through each bird's story branch as you're left sitting through a lot of repetitive text again and again.Now don't get me wrong - some of the storylines are truly adorable Ryouta! <3, a handful aren't afraid pull hard on your heartstrings Nageki ;_;, while others are legitimately insane and make me worry for the developers Shuu and Oko both take the cake (or pudding?) on this one. But after a while, the number of new choices you make in comparison to the amount of old text you have to skip through skews unfavourably, and has probably stopped thousands of people from perservering with getting all the endings. It's just a bird dating gimmick, so why play any more - right? But it's a real shame, as by dropping out early they miss the actual end to the game... which is where the real meat of Hatoful Boyfriend lies. What was once a bizarre, fluffy visual novel turns into... well. I don't want to give too much of the game away, but what I can say is this; the final ending for Hatoful Boyfriend masterfully elevates a goofy gimmick into one of the most breath-taking segments of in-game storytelling I have ever come across. What the developers have managed to do with a few still shots and some bird photographs is spectacular, and I will never be able to sing enough praise for the range and depth of emotion this final chapter hauled me through. I also love how skilfully all the other endings feed into the story being told, and after completing it you'll completely understand the developer's decision to make it inaccessible until you've seen everything else first.TL;DR: Hatoful Boyfriend is simultaneously as much of a car crash as it is a masterpiece, and if you are a fan of gaming classics then I cannot recommend this little gem of a title enough. There's a long, hilarious, bizarre and eventually boring lead-up to the real meat of the game, but if you can stay patient and let yourself warm up to the crazy cast of characters the game has to offer, your efforts will be rewarded with a level of storytelling that puts many bigger titles to shame. If you were actually after a dating sim then don't expect anything too romantic or racey - the storylines are fluffy at best and heartbreaking at worst. 'Dating sim' might be the cutesy pink wrapping paper, but it's the emotional journey you are taken on which lies at the heart of this wonderously endearing game.Eleven out of ten... would cry my god damn heart out for Ryouta again.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												Initially, Hatoful Boyfriend struck me as a purely comedic otome game. Like many who chose to play it, I decided to go through it for kicks. Eventually, I learned that it is not what it seems at all. The more I progressed through the game the more immersed I became in it. I forgot all about the fact that it was meant to be a dating simulator where you court birds. I learned that it possesses all the trappings of classic visual novels. It is rife with plot twists and angst. The story is surprisingly deep, something I found to be a relief. As you go through the routes you obtain more and more pieces of the proverbial puzzle. They fit together pretty nicely at the end. I was glad to know that it is more than just some silly thing.Although it has many elements and troupes that are common in such games it presented them in a unique way, I think. However, my taste for it was admittedly acquired. After having went through a route in its entirety I became bored of many of the jokes and scenarios which had been scattered throughout it. For a time it was a bit of a chore to go through. Thankfully, the skip button helps you rush through the things you have already read, cutting out unnecessary game-time. You definitely need to be patient when going through Hatoful Boyfriend. I personally feel that in order to get the most enjoyment out of it you should go through one route at a time. That way you will have plenty of time to reflect on what happened as well as keep your interest in the plot fresh.PROS:> Overall, Hatoful Boyfriend is short and sweet. A basic route can be finished in an hour even if you are a slow reader. This makes it a great thing to play before going to bed or when you just need to kill some time for a while.> The art is soft, and the scenery colorful, making the backdrops pleasant. It is simple, but is still able to add to the mood.> While many of the characters and their stories are tried-and-true they are still ones you can get attached to (for the most part, anyway).> There is more than one unlockable route.> The story becomes more advanced as you progress through the game.CONS:> The protagonist is simple and impressionable.> During the main routes you do not get a lot of route-exclusive content. A lot of the scenarios are the ones you go through during the main story, so you end up having to read through much of what you already have.> The running gags get old fast.> You are unable to save at decision screens and must do so just before you are about to make a choice.> There are very few CGs.> Sometimes your saves will bring you to a backdrop and you cannot do anything at all so you have to exit and re-open the game (save your game in multiple slots just in case!).All in all, I think that Hatoful Boyfriend is enjoyable. I feel that it rewards you well for your diligence. The final, true story that is Hatoful Boyfriend is great. I absolutely love the BBL ending, and think that it was worth all the time I spent working to get it. I believe that it is a fairly solid purchase.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Here is a game as joyous and painful, as mysterious and memorable, as high school itself. Hatoful Boyfriend captures the longing of the lonely, the brute insult of bigotry, and the wonder of even the most simplistic actions making the world feel right again in post-apocalyptic dystopian future. Compassionate, dramatic, this is writing that always knows when to take a moment for humor AND pathos. Let the deep and highly metaphoric story sink in over multiple playthroughs or you will be missing out on some of the best divergent storytelling of the generation.As you click through interaction after interaction just know that others are out there are taking time to do the same. Slowly begin to realize that some people can be trusted. It was people that made this game, after all, people finally aware of the  consumer fatigue of space marines and dragons. You may never fully rehabilitate into a properly functioning member of human society by their standards but you understand, just as I understand, that it is people that we do NOT understand. Remember, birds can be trusted, birds always come back. Some people are meant to be with people, and others, like us, are just different. We may not have the shiniest of neck feathers and our ultimate failing is to be aware that we are not aware. But we have finally found somewhere we can live in peace.Let us never forget the healing power of columbidae society but let us always try to remember to wash our berries before we eat them. Our digestive and respiratory systems may be different but blood is pumped into the heart from the body through the veins, the blood then enters the right atrium, then gets transported through the right ventricle and then is moved to into the lungs and oxygenated just the same."In some things they shame us, by and large. Once mated, they are wed for life, unless forcibly separated. When set to the task, such as a long race, they will persevere and endure through measures of hell that only the best of men will willingly undertake. It might be argued that they are simply, dumbly, following the programming of instinct, that they can do nothing differently. Perhaps that can be said of us as well."- Where Pigeons Go to Die.

Posted: September 24, 2016
												I have been so excitedly telling everyone about this game I actually forgot to properly review it.It's a bit late now, but for the principle of it:This is a perfect parody of dating sims - which laughs WITH fans of the genre instead of laughing AT them - used as a long-form introductory wrapping to a marvelous, intensely emotional visual novel about dreams, friendship and hope.… with pigeons.Although I had heard of the game since its release in English, i couldn't play it and stayd away from spoilers and forums, and I am SO glad I did! The impact of wandering the various storylines is so much more intense when you have no idea what's about to happen… The game manages to surprise & shock you almost every. single. time, despite your probable initial expectations that "a dating sim with pigeons? NOTHING will shock me any more…" JUST. YOU. WAIT.I have the deepest respect and admiration for the author, who managed to take a lighthearted April's fools joke demo and turn it into such a well-thought, deep and engaging real story… without sacrificing any of the initial fun & WTFness. This is a masterpiece of storytelling.And yet, when all is over and you're still reeling from the emotional rollercoaster that is the second half of the game (for best effect, play the "fulfilling a promise" path LAST, and in one single sitting!), the only way you feel you can describe the game to outsiders still seems to be : "it's a dating sim… but with pigeons. And then it gets INTENSE, and you will cry."10/10, would cry again.PS: Okosan is the most precious cinnamon r- err, pudding of all birdies, and deserves all the hugs.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												It's a cute game about birds. What's not to love? You play as a girl, named default Hiyoko Tosaka, a human girl that goes to Saint Pigeonation's, a prestigious academy for the pigeon and by the pigeon. You will follow her journey and meet all kinds of friends and fowls, and maybe even fall in love! However, all is not well in Japan, as you find out more secrets as to why there aren't many humans. Will your high school days stay cheery and fun, will they be full of romance, or is something more fishy afoot? Date a total of 8 different pigeons and meet all kinds of feathery folk in Hatoful Boyfriend!Plays like a game, reads like a story! The gameplay is simple enough: Click a choice, read the story. Unlike some games of this genre, Hatoful Boyfriend doesn't have any gimmicks like buying certain routes (All are included! Hooray~), building stats (They are important, but not super important), giving gifts, waiting for specific times to talk to characters, etc.Hatoful Boyfriend is a VISUAL NOVEL, so you will enjoy a unique story depending on the choices you make. The game has a ton of different endings, good and bad, to get, so there are quite a few achievements to acquire. In all seriousness, Hatoful Boyfriend is probably my favorite Visual Novel for a lot of reasons despite it's unusual subject matter. It's funny, it has likeable characters, and a pretty wacky plot that you would never figure out without doing at least 3 or more routes. However, this game isn't just humorous. It'll also take your heart and rip it apart S L O W L Y on certain routes, especially Ryouta's and the Even though it's not serious like a lot of Otome VNs, especially the popular ones of today (i.e. Mystic Messenger), it's entertaining and definitely a good entry-level Otome game due to its simplicity. Although it's a parody, it's a really well done parody - and I'm glad this was my first entry to dating sims and visual novels at a whole. Do I recommend Hatoful Boyfriend? Well yeah, of course. It's a really well-thought out and equally outrageous game, and Hato Moa is a great writer. Every story is just as entertaining as the last, and even bad ends leave you salivating for more. The translation (This game is obviously from Japan if you couldn't tell) is very nice and free of pretty much any errors. There are no glitches or bugs from what I know. Hatoful Boyfriend is a very good game for the price, especially when you consider the fact that this is an HD remake of the original game. Yes, you heard me right, a HD remake. I've been playing since the original (which is included with the collector's edition! Yippee!) was first translated and the free version was out. I'm very pleased with the HD remaster and the fact that I can play a specific birdie's route that wasn't in the free original and that there's basically way more that the original game didn't offer at all, free or paid.If you're unsure about playing Hatoful Boyfriend, pick it up when it's on sale or hope someone gifts it to you (which I recommend to do after you've enjoyed this game - GIVE THE GIFT OF PIGEON LOVE!). It's not the most expensive game you'll ever play, but it may be a bit pricy for those who are not sure about playing VNs. That's ok though! Even if you get it on sale or as a gift, it's definitely a good purchase. I've poured hours into the original.If you enjoy/enjoyed Hatoful BF, definitely check out the successor, Hatoful Boyfriend Holiday Star, for holiday-themed madness with your favorite birdies.
