												I have been so excitedly telling everyone about this game I actually forgot to properly review it.It's a bit late now, but for the principle of it:This is a perfect parody of dating sims - which laughs WITH fans of the genre instead of laughing AT them - used as a long-form introductory wrapping to a marvelous, intensely emotional visual novel about dreams, friendship and hope.… with pigeons.Although I had heard of the game since its release in English, i couldn't play it and stayd away from spoilers and forums, and I am SO glad I did! The impact of wandering the various storylines is so much more intense when you have no idea what's about to happen… The game manages to surprise & shock you almost every. single. time, despite your probable initial expectations that "a dating sim with pigeons? NOTHING will shock me any more…" JUST. YOU. WAIT.I have the deepest respect and admiration for the author, who managed to take a lighthearted April's fools joke demo and turn it into such a well-thought, deep and engaging real story… without sacrificing any of the initial fun & WTFness. This is a masterpiece of storytelling.And yet, when all is over and you're still reeling from the emotional rollercoaster that is the second half of the game (for best effect, play the "fulfilling a promise" path LAST, and in one single sitting!), the only way you feel you can describe the game to outsiders still seems to be : "it's a dating sim… but with pigeons. And then it gets INTENSE, and you will cry."10/10, would cry again.PS: Okosan is the most precious cinnamon r- err, pudding of all birdies, and deserves all the hugs.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												First and foremost for those that fail to read the information above this is a visual novel. That means the majority of the content is reading. If you dislike reading turn back now.Alright. For those of you still here yes this game is satire, but it can also take itself quite seriously. While playing this you have the amusing routes(which can overlap), the tear-jerking routes(which can overlap), the childhood friend route, the jerkwad routes, the senpai route, the sensei route, and the reformed thug/female route. Additionally there's the secret plot-heavy route that will not be spoken of for the sake of spoilers. The gameplay is much like you'd expect from a visual novel. Make a few choices. If you select the correct ones and have the proper stats congrats. You just landed yourself a good ending. Speaking of stats they aren't used as much as the other games of the same read-and-select format. An amusing game at the core for the most part.Now what this rerelease was mainly supposed to fix was the engine. You see the previous engine back before the steam version was riddled with bugs and made playing it rather difficult. While this engine does run much more smoothly than Famous Writer did it does, in fact, have some bugs too. There have been reports of freezing on a white screen during the loading process before getting to the menu, crashing when loading human portraits, and likely more that have yet to be reported. Thankfully these aren't as numerous as the previous iteration. Still annoying, but some have reported fixing it by restarting the game. As per the others... Well this is a custom engine. Perhaps there will be patches in the future to fix the problems.As per double the original price... Moa used a lot of open sourse content to make the game as cheap as possible at first, and this remake gave the game its own look background-wise as well as replacing that outdated freeware engine. The music is the same and the birds are higher resolution, but more or less the same. That said some of the birds are higher resolution than the other birds.All in all I still do recommend it since it is less likely to backfire on you than the original and does provide a good deal of amusement.Edit: It slipped my mind earlier, but the collector's edition does hold true on its claim. The original game is included if you feel like owning both renditions.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												I have a love-hate relationship with dating sims. I love almost everything about their writing, the nature of the narrative slowly unfolding non-linearly with each replay, and the exploration of character and testing the player's understanding of character. I love also how it critically looks at various staples of love-interests in romance in a way that romance novels rarely do. We have more than just the standard alpha-male. What I don't like about dating sims is that I have yet to find one which lets me just skip (not fast-forward - SKIP) scenes I've seen before and the sheer amount of grinding involved in stat building. Sometimes I want to do-away with stat-building completely and take a page out of Moacube's book where you have other types of decisions which advance plot define your character's character and "stats". Hatoful tries to make stat building more connected to plot by actually providing you with a unique scene along with each stat building time point. However, I still found the stat building unecessary. I also found the needing to romance a character in two different ways in order to unlock the epilogue really...arduously boring. That said, Hatoful Boyfriend improves on a lot of other dating sim mechanics and really invests in taking the player's preconceptions of whimsy and istead offers a genuinely good science fiction story. There is a lot of depth in this game should you commit to seeking it and a lot of heart. I still await the day where we work towards dating sims that remove grinding, whether that's re-doing vast stretches of story to get to new scenes or improve (or do away with) the stat building. Sadly, Hatoful Boyfriend still suffers from both, though to a lesser extent than the average dating sim. This detracted from my experience. I still heartily recommend this game as amongst one of the top games you can play in its genre. (Seriously.)

content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												The game is pretty entertaining because the writing is good and the idea of dating pigeons is funny.  The characters are great, all with distinct personalities, including the main character.  Unlike some other dating sims, it doesn't branch off into a separate route for each character you date --instead, the new stuff for each character is interspersed between scenes common to each character... expect to be hitting the skip button a lot.  The amount of new content for each character is pretty good, though.The real meat of the game is when you unlock the final route after completing all the other routes.  To put this in perspective, there are 15 endings (not counting an epilogue).  I read all of the dialogue out loud with my friend, using the skip button for dialogue we already saw before.  It took 10 hours to do the 14 normal routes and 6 hours to do the final route alone-- that's how big the difference is.  So make sure you do the final route, since it's a huge amount of the game and it really ties everything together well.Where the game fell short for me was in the implementation.  There were a number of annoying technical aspects that really detracted from the game.  One was the skip button, which sometimes failed to skip past old dialogue and would also skip past new dialogue.  Another big one was the save games, which do not work if you have the game installed somewhere other than your C drive-- a real annoyance with the really long final route.  And then there were just some small annoyances like unnecessary extra clicks (such as having to click twice before every choice), the slow speed of the scene transitions, and a ton of typos... which were actually kind of entertaining, but still.Even so, the game is worth playing.  It might not be the most polished VN you'll ever play, but it has some solid writing and is just a really fun experience.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												This game is one of those rare few that seems like its one thing, and then it ends up being something much, MUCH, greater than expected. Going into it you might think its just a weird Japanese visual novel about dating birds. And, well, it sort of is. But what you wouldn't know without playing it is just how much more there is to this game. The vast amount of diversity speaks volumes of the effort put into making this game the experience that it is. Although it is classed as a dating sim, this is one of the few games that tackles many other genres, and actually does it well. Basically, each of the different characters' story lines you can follow are unique to one another. Each character has a very different personality and backstory, as well as their routes have their own uniqe themes and plots that other characters routes don't necessarily have a focus on. This is what makes this such a great game, because it makes you WANT to complete every route so you can learn the whole story, rather than making you feel like you have to suffer through several playthroughs of the same thing to get the end result. Each of the different characters stories are enjoyable and entertaing in their own unique way, be it a sweet romance, or a bone-chilling mystery, they are all very different.Then of course, there is the secret "true ending" story route, wheather it can be called that or not, it is one of the most fantastic works of story telling I have ever experienced in a visual novel. I'm not going to spoil anything, as it really should be played without any prior knowledge or spoilers, but I strongly encourage players to play through every possible story route even if some may be silly at times, as that's what gives this game its charm. Each one of the stories you can play through will entertain you with silly jokes, emotion evoking plots, or even suspensful and horrorific secrets. Then after all those memorable events, you will be able to enjoy yet another very unique, very interesting, and very well written and played out "true ending" scenario. I could talk for hours about how great all the individual routes and the overarching plots are, but it is truely something that is best left for you, the player, to discover by playing the game for yourselves.If you havn't yet bought Hatoful Boyfriend, or are maybe considering the purchase but are unsure if you will enjoy it, then you have my reccomendation to buy and play this game, and  that it will be something that you'll be able to enjoy playing, and re-playing, for a very long time to come. For the amount of content this game has, it is definately worth buying. Through all of its silly laughs, its shocking secrets, and its heartbreaking emotional moments, Hatoful Boyfriend has become a personal favourite, and hopefully you will enjoy it too.

												I first bought this game when it first came out (Sept 2014), on sale, as a gag gift for my friend. I didn't understand why it was $10 for a dating game about birds, so I never bothered with it at full price. Me and some friends had some laughs going through one of the endings and it wasn't touched much since.Fast Forward to the 2015 Summer Sale. I bought 3 copies of Hatoful Boyfriend - again, on a huge sale. I'm the cheap friend - and gave two of the copies to friends, and saved one for myself to play for some small laughs. Get an ending or two, waste some time. But as I got more endings, I learned more and more about the world I was thrown into, and just how intriguing it was. And I learned more and more about the characters I'm around, and how everything fits together more than one would find in a simple dating simulator - human or otherwise. Three and a half hours later:I have gone through eight different endings. I have nearly cried twice, and completely ragequit once. I have been piecing the world together and it is an outstanding place. I have come to understand just why it is worth its full pricetag, and feel dirty having only paid a cut price for this. In short, Hatoful Boyfriend is a top contender to being one of my favorite games ever. It deserves the chance to being yours too.

												This isn't just a dating sim with birds - it's much, much more. It challenges the social standings of humans and their place in the world - the world that humans have altered themselves for the greater good, only to have their creations turn against them. It touches upon the existance of the supernatural, and the consequences of mingling with fate and the higher order. The juxtaposition between the birds and the humans is highlighted as you interact with key characters. You will have to face with and debate against (or for) political issues that will directly affect your well-being. The more you, a human, gets involved into these affairs, the more you unravel about the hidden mystery behind St. PigeoNation Institute of Littledove Hachiman City. Would definitely recommend - you will not be disappointed.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												I bought the Collector's Edition so I will do a small review of the game and a look over the extras you get.I love visual novels and when I first got this game I thought it was going to be a very sweet but quite gimmicky. I played the demo on the original site and boy was I wrong. Yes the game can indeed be very sweet but it can also be very dark. The game had a depth and was so well written that I had never expected. Now I will say I have played LOADS of visual novel games and am very finicky about which ones I buy. The moment this game came to Steam I bought it the first moment I noticed it was there. Its well written, the characters are well developed and believeable (with the exception of Okasan and Aghel but that's how they are supposed to be), the music is lovely and well fitted to the areas they are used, it had multiple endings which depended on your stats in some cases, you actually LEARN the birds names which were chosen to represent the men you can be with in this game and its just engrossing. The game itself is a definite recommend.Now I will look at the extra you get with Hatoful Boyfriend Collectors Edition:It comes with the soundtrack which as I said its a lovely soundtrack and it seems to include all of the songs. The wallpapers was disappointing. It just came with two wallpapers featuring the purple heart background and fantail pigeons. The comic is short but sweet. Each character has two mini comics (4 frames) after them. It doesn't add to the story in any way its just quite sweet. Though there was only one that made me laugh.The yearbook. I will say this now its not a yearbook. Its actually just a virtual artbook made to look like a yearbook which disappointed me greatly. I hoped it would be Tosaka's year book with pictures of her class inside and signed with a message from each of the main characters but no such luck. The art work is quite nice but not what I was expecting. The actual game is definitely worth a buy but the collector's edition I'd advise you only get if it was on offer for a £1 or two (three if you really want it) Its not worth its £5 price tag.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												The first VN I have played in my life, and one of the more enjoyable VNs I have experienced in my life as well (which isn't a lot mind you). Hatoful Boyfriend is about dating birds, and over time, finding out the events that lead to a human girl attending a pigeon school and forming romantic relationships with them. Hatoful plays with its unique premise, leading the way for pigeon related antics and such. The comedy is great in the VN, the drama fits, and everything works out. The staff even managed to fit in a number of anime or japanese pop culture references into the show as well, which may or may not be your thing (it definitely was enjoyable for me). The second part of the VN, is where a lot of the history of the setting is explained, and trades all of the comedy and silliness for drama. The drama is decent, the payoff is pretty meh, the story and background is pretty well done and fleshed out. The second part is also incredibly long, like hours long, just a warning.Overall Hatoful Boyfriend is an enjoyable experience. Each route is quite special in its own way, and they each have a certain charm to them. Having to perfect this game didn't bother me at all, as I had fun playing it all the way through.

												So far I've only unlocked 3 endings, but I also got the "Bad Ending" (and its achievement)! Jeez. It's simple and easy to read, and once you know the main arc you can hammer your mouse through it to get to new content for new boyfriends really fast. High Points:-The story is interesting and there's no shortage of drama, for sure (If you came for anything else in a dating sim, you're in the wrong place).-Lots of variation! My favorite birdie is Yuuya, but I don't think I have a least favorite. They're all super fun and creatively designed.-This game keeps surprising me.Low Points:-There probably won't be a lot of replayability :/-Yuuya's romance was hard to figure out; I got the Bad Ending just trying the first go around, and Ryouta fell in love with me the second time. I ended up looking up the first couple steps to get myself on the right track. I also have no idea how to romance Azumi. This game gives you goals and no instruction manual!-The soundtrack kind of bothers me. It doesn't fade or change evenly, but stops abruptly when scenes shift or ends when a scene times out (I left my computer for a while and came back and the game was absolutely silent). That's par for the course for a lot of dating sims though.If you like anime pigeons and you need something for a quiet evening in, this is a good filler :o) each romance only takes about 30-45 minutes. 8/10

Posted: December 5, 2015
												I can't believe I'm about to say this, but I believe Hatoful Boyfriend just might be one of the best games I have ever played. Please hear me out first before you call me crazy! (Warning: spoilers ahead) I believe you are supposed to follow the romances in the order of the achievement list to maximise the effect. It starts out as what you'd expect: a simple dating sim where you can romance birds. But as you go along, the supernatural becomes more evident, with ghosts and weird pudding gods (???) and fallen angels and reincarnations and stuff. And then you get to the highlight of the game. The BBL ending. Whereas the 14 other endings took me about five to six hours to complete, I was staring at my screen for like three hours for this, and I couldn't stop no matter how much my eyes hurt. It's madness. What started as a cute bird romance sim became some weird combination of horror and mystery, with a conspiracy that tied practically every single main character to each other in some way or other. The hints have been there all along, even in the "normal" romance routes, but after playing this you'll understand everything, and your mind will be blown away. On a sidenote, I wonder what kind of drugs the makers had to take to think of this kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10/10 would rather play Hatoful Boyfriend BBL ending than watch/read Game of Thrones.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Where do I stat with this? It's difficult to classify this game as something other than a dating sim, because it can become more than that depending on your choices. It's also very difficult to discuss this game without resorting to "omg look at this wacky game! It's soooooooo random! XD" Don't let the Pewdiepie hype portrayed by many streamers deter you from even glancing at this due to your disgust. Those people are the same idiots that also scream, "Dark Souls is too hard! Golly, this is so epic!"I can say, first and foremost, that this is a visual novel. Regardless of sub-genre, that's what this boils down to. It's a very intriguing visual novel. It performs under the guise of a classic Japanese high school dating sim while donning the peculiar gimmick of having birds for the school's students. While this may sound extremely gimmicky, and I won't lie, it is. That is not necessarily a bad thing though! This allows for a different kind of exploration into one's feelings. Can you get emotionally attatched to a bird to some degree? You would not think so, but these birds are essentially people-type characters. They talk, have inner/outter conflicts, and even run in marathons. I can also imagine the same could happen if it was a high school of Super Robots, but it's not. That would be an awesome game. We need that to be on Steam right now.If you're still interested at this point you'd might as well start reading further into this. Let's face it; if you're interested in a dating sim with birds, then you probably have few other things to entertain you at this point in terms of modern gaming.Would I even like a dating sim with birds where I would not be able to even date females? That's how I felt, but I was tired of the typical tropes of AAA games and decided that I would instead let myself fall victim to the cliches of standardized Japanese gaming this time around. I was absolutely correct in the aspect of dating sim cliches remaining intact, but I was not prepared for the fact that there are routes that rip the afforementioned apart. If you're reading through Fate/Stay Night, then of course you'd expect things to become intense and heavy. When you play an average dating sim you're just expecting two people to get together and happy things ensue with a nice ending, save for School Days. That was just depressing on about every level.You won't expect things once they hit you in Hatoful Boyfriend, and that is the true glory of the writing in this game. It just happens to be covered in a feathery layer topped with a beak.I fully recommend this title to visual novel enthusiasts, or anyone who just wants to dive into the visual novel genre for their first time. With a title like this being easily accessible to a North American audience on Steam, there has never been a better time to start!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												The first VN I have played in my life, and one of the more enjoyable VNs I have experienced in my life as well (which isn't a lot mind you). Hatoful Boyfriend is about dating birds, and over time, finding out the events that lead to a human girl attending a pigeon school and forming romantic relationships with them. Hatoful plays with its unique premise, leading the way for pigeon related antics and such. The comedy is great in the VN, the drama fits, and everything works out. The staff even managed to fit in a number of anime or japanese pop culture references into the show as well, which may or may not be your thing (it definitely was enjoyable for me). The second part of the VN, is where a lot of the history of the setting is explained, and trades all of the comedy and silliness for drama. The drama is decent, the payoff is pretty meh, the story and background is pretty well done and fleshed out. The second part is also incredibly long, like hours long, just a warning.Overall Hatoful Boyfriend is an enjoyable experience. Each route is quite special in its own way, and they each have a certain charm to them. Having to perfect this game didn't bother me at all, as I had fun playing it all the way through.

												So far I've only unlocked 3 endings, but I also got the "Bad Ending" (and its achievement)! Jeez. It's simple and easy to read, and once you know the main arc you can hammer your mouse through it to get to new content for new boyfriends really fast. High Points:-The story is interesting and there's no shortage of drama, for sure (If you came for anything else in a dating sim, you're in the wrong place).-Lots of variation! My favorite birdie is Yuuya, but I don't think I have a least favorite. They're all super fun and creatively designed.-This game keeps surprising me.Low Points:-There probably won't be a lot of replayability :/-Yuuya's romance was hard to figure out; I got the Bad Ending just trying the first go around, and Ryouta fell in love with me the second time. I ended up looking up the first couple steps to get myself on the right track. I also have no idea how to romance Azumi. This game gives you goals and no instruction manual!-The soundtrack kind of bothers me. It doesn't fade or change evenly, but stops abruptly when scenes shift or ends when a scene times out (I left my computer for a while and came back and the game was absolutely silent). That's par for the course for a lot of dating sims though.If you like anime pigeons and you need something for a quiet evening in, this is a good filler :o) each romance only takes about 30-45 minutes. 8/10

Posted: January 20, 2015
												I bought the Collector's Edition so I will do a small review of the game and a look over the extras you get.I love visual novels and when I first got this game I thought it was going to be a very sweet but quite gimmicky. I played the demo on the original site and boy was I wrong. Yes the game can indeed be very sweet but it can also be very dark. The game had a depth and was so well written that I had never expected. Now I will say I have played LOADS of visual novel games and am very finicky about which ones I buy. The moment this game came to Steam I bought it the first moment I noticed it was there. Its well written, the characters are well developed and believeable (with the exception of Okasan and Aghel but that's how they are supposed to be), the music is lovely and well fitted to the areas they are used, it had multiple endings which depended on your stats in some cases, you actually LEARN the birds names which were chosen to represent the men you can be with in this game and its just engrossing. The game itself is a definite recommend.Now I will look at the extra you get with Hatoful Boyfriend Collectors Edition:It comes with the soundtrack which as I said its a lovely soundtrack and it seems to include all of the songs. The wallpapers was disappointing. It just came with two wallpapers featuring the purple heart background and fantail pigeons. The comic is short but sweet. Each character has two mini comics (4 frames) after them. It doesn't add to the story in any way its just quite sweet. Though there was only one that made me laugh.The yearbook. I will say this now its not a yearbook. Its actually just a virtual artbook made to look like a yearbook which disappointed me greatly. I hoped it would be Tosaka's year book with pictures of her class inside and signed with a message from each of the main characters but no such luck. The art work is quite nice but not what I was expecting. The actual game is definitely worth a buy but the collector's edition I'd advise you only get if it was on offer for a £1 or two (three if you really want it) Its not worth its £5 price tag.

												I don't know where to even begin with this game. Hatoful was bought for me by a close friend who thought that a bird dating simulator would be a nice joke gift for someone who likes birds so much. HB is both absolutely ridiculous and eerily macabre. 10/10, best bird dating sim

The Pudding Is A LieMy lady made me play this one.  I did so on her account (hence the time played).  She found all possible endings, some of which I witnessed; I personally completed just one playthrough.  One was enough; thanks, Oko-san.I'm now that much more acquainted with just how strange the realm of videogaming can be, though I'm not precisely elated at the advent of this hard won wisdom.Dating sims are just odd to begin with, but Hato Moa & friends really tried hard to provide eyebrow-raising occasions.  Gotta hand it to them, Hatoful Boyfriend is at times clever & laugh inducing - in the "what on god's green earth is happening here" kind of way.If like me this caught your eye because it was published by Devolver Digital, just know it's easily their most "out there" title to date.Against the prospect of preserving my already beleaguered sanity, they went & made a Hatoful Boyfriend: Holiday Star Christmas-themed sequel..Silly review for a silly game.  Thumbs up & anyone who disagrees is a bird brain!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Oh boy...I want to say so much, yet I have no words to express my feelings.First of all this is not one game but two. First one is a dating simulator and what an oddball it is! It has both comedy and tragedy in it but in fact it serves only for one purpose. To distract and fool you, to entangle you in lies. And what is the best lie? Yes, it's truth in a small doses. It introduces almost every personage in the game to you, but only fractions of their story and personality are real, that ones which lie right on the surface. It have many routes and their stories are nice but that's not all. All these stories are only a massive distraction and they serve their purpose very well. If you will ever make it to the second part you will be even more puzzled by the unraveling events.The second part is completely different from the first one. It is not a dating sim but kinetic novel and that's where the true and deep story lie. To be honest I got bored before I finally got to it but now when I finished it I have nothing to regret. It worth every second spent in the first part and a lot more.Pudding / 10

Posted: November 9, 2015
												Listen, I know.It's a visual-novel-dating-sim thing, featuring birds.It's one of those things that sounds like a game played by straw-man nerd losers in a cartoon.However, it's a surprisingly engaging and deep story, with a level of content connectedness that is truly excessive.Excessive because it all works so stupidly well. I went into this thinking it was going to be a silly, stupid, amusing romp.I emerged feeling 100% on board with calling it art, even to the point of being comfortable actively endorsing people play the game, despite the, uh, unsavory impression it may make to say "No really, play this game where you try to bone birds"10/10Side note: I played this with a group of friends, and we read the whole thing aloud, in stupid voices. I'm sure that added to the enjoyment, but keep in mind that the game will become increasingly dark and serious, and the voices may rob some emotional scenes of their gravitas(again, I know, I'm talking about the bird-boning game).

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just the hilarious pigeon dating sim you see on the surface. Radical political parties, genocide, experimentation, biological warfare, murder, pudding--just to name a few--are all themes you'll encounter in this game.You are a human transfer student in a school specifically for birds. Unbeknownst to you, your mission is to woo every bird in the school, albeit one at a time in separate playthroughs. Each bird has different interests, personalities, and backstories, but the more you play, the more you'll realize that they're all intertwined, and that there's something terribly sinister going on at your school behind the scenes. Once you've seduced every bird and achieved every ending, you are rewarded with a chance to "fulfill the promise," and solve a mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat for hours.Hatoful Boyfriend is beyond deceptive in its marketing as a joke, and I hadn't expected that it would tell a wonderfully written story that would leave me in tears at its end.--My only gripe about Hatoful Boyfriend is the spotty save system, as so many others seem to have issues with, too. I would occasionally need to load a save only to find that it would load a background without characters, text, or interface, forcing me to Alt+F4 to leave the game. The save file was forever corrupted, and I would have to restart that particular storyline. The dating playthroughs are short enough to finish in single sittings, but the finale can take hours to finish. I would recommend playing the finale only if you know you have a lot of free time ahead of you, at least until the save issues are fixed. I will amend this review should they be resolved.Oh, and the occasional typo or missing word, but that's not a big deal.--Have fun, everybirdie!

												I can't believe the day has come when I can unironically recommend a video game about dating pigeons, but to be fair I did also unironically recommend Euro Truck Simulator 2.Hatoful Boyfriend (if you're wondering, "hatoful" could be read as "heartful" or "hurtful"; and also triples as a pun to the Japanese kanji for pigeon) shows that no matter how silly the premise, you can still make a great story out of it. What originally started out as a visual novel about dating pigeons, eventually becomes a visual novel about dating pigeons with deep and complex personalities.The game (or should I say the visual novel) itself is nothing complex, the closest thing to gameplay here is making a decision. Though your decision will ultimately decide who you choose to get close with and how the game ends.Speaking of the story, it is quite entertaining. The writing is fantastic, and all of the characters have their own lovable quirks, in fact the route you take can vastly affect the mood of the story. After going on a certain route, you can do the hidden route which unless you've gotten all the ending (which includes both the normal and true ending for every character) you won't see the epilogue. Getting all of the ending means you have to read through a lot of the things you've read before, there is a fast forward button; but sometimes new dialogues could appear in a scene that you expected to play as usual.Overall Hatoful Boyfriend is an entertaining visual novel about dating pigeons...That was anti-climatic.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												When I first saw this game, my thoughts were: “what even”. When I bought and played the game, my thoughts were “what EVEN”. Now, after finishing it (in multiple ways!) and reviewing it, my thoughts are “WHAT EVEN”.I just. What. What even?So it’s a visual novel. About dating birds. As a human girl. In a school for birds. And you WILL adore the birds, fall in love with the birds, cry at the birds, and then stare at the credits in disbelief because did all of that just happen in the span of an hour?And then you’ll do all of it again. Seven times.For real though, this game is brilliant. That said, it is definitely not the best game ever. It does manage to be humorous and serious at the same time, and generally at the right times (at least to one familiar with Japanese storytelling conventions).The downside is the length: in terms of raw content, Hatoful Boyfriend falls a bit short. It’s true there are eight character routes, plus a couple alternatives and extras, but each route only takes about forty to sixty minutes to complete, and that time gets progressively shorter each time you play: a lot of the text is exactly the same regardless of route taken. Aside from taking different classes each day – which there aren’t that many – the contents of the game won’t change much until about 3/4ths through, where you’re finally locked into a specific route.Still, the story of the game is very engaging. Though the premise and the world is built on humor, the story takes itself very seriously. Each character is fully fleshed out and their routes just sweep you along for the adventure, and the setting the game builds is solid and easy to get into once you accept the wacky premise. The writing itself isn’t exactly superb, but I dare you to name a VN that has that. What matters is that the humor actually manages to be funny, the emotional scenes are actually touching, and the happy scenes are sweet but not over the top. The final product feels very genuine, and that makes up for its shortcomings.Play this game. You will only regret not playing it sooner.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												"Ha, pigeons? How weird. Let's buy this game, just for fun." Most people say this before purchasing this game. I know. I did in 2012 when it first came out on another website. I bought the game and decided to go for the most familiar bird to me. The Mourning Dove, Nageki.  A young boy who died too young. He was put in a medical centre because of his weak immune system. He had a disease, the H5N1 virus. It was able to kill the humans that killed Nageki's family. However, he didn't want to kill the humans. He said he couldn't live anymore, so he threw himself into the fire he lit in the centre's basement.	 This game turned sad when I reached his ending. I decided to replay it, this time going for the fluffball of a partridge, Shuu, or shall I say  Isa Souma.	 His ending made this game much darker. I decided to play the rest of the game. After I played Ryouta's ending, a new choice popped up. I could fulfill a promise. I didn't know it at the time, but I wasn't Hiyoko when I made the choice. I was the Doctor. Shuu wanted to fulfill the promise he made to someone he loved. The game switched genres before my eyes. It went from a supposedly silly dating simulator to a horrifying murder mystery with pigeons. This game, while being amazing, has a few flaws, but they are quite small compared to the pros. The grammar isn't very good compared to some games, but what do you expect from a game translated into English from Japanese. There are also numerous plot holes that aren't solved unless you buy the sequel, Holiday Star. Like  why Hitori bleached his feathers. Most believe that it was to hide his true identity to get revenge on Shuu. While that is true, there is a second reason.Overall, this game is fantastic. It gets you hooked on the eerie and sad twists and then just makes a 360 turn into pigeon hell. There is no escaping now.Rating8 running Okosan's out of 10.

Evidently there was good reason, as you progress through the game, making choices, interacting with possible husbandoves, and taken twists and turns, the experience overall is ridiculous.  It is a fun game, and great that it offers a fast forward option when you want to skip sections you have read already (such as the beginning).  Progressing through the story isn't terribly long for most endings, and trying to get each birdies ending is fairly straight forward.  This game is easily replayable, especially when you unlock more endings, and can easily get you hooked.  I suggest buying it on sale, however full price isn't terrible either.My only quarrel is sometimes getting a full ending for a character may not always be clear cut, and thus having to restart a new game may be cumborsome, and one of the endings took a little longer than I would have liked (regardless of how interesting it got).It's a great game and earns and 8 out of 10 stars.Something Everbirdie would love, so go find your husbandoveP.S. I'm putting this game as a nomination for The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award.  This game, with little advertising, is actually a very fun game, even for those who don't typically enjoy visual novels. I'll update my review if my nominee changes.

I mean, I've never played dating sims before but I assumed they don't have complex storylines. If anything, I never thought the game has a rich storyline on its own (BBL ending). That's when you'll understand why people like this game.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This game took me completely by surprise.Everything about Hatoful Boyfriend suggested that it wasn't anything more than a joke. I expected to play this game for an hour, show it to my friends, have a good laugh, and move on. What I didn't expect, was just how much this game would impact me on a deeper level.The story starts off slow, gradually introducing you to each bird. This is the part of the game where the concept is at its most ludicrous. Bird puns are thrown around with reckless enthusiasm, and you'd be forgiven for assuming that the rest of the story would follow in the same comedic vein. However, there's a much darker tale lying just beneath the surface. I don't want to spoil anything here, but suffice to say that these birds have issues. Tragic pasts, entertwining dramas, bleak outlooks, sinister plans, and a caveat of other unexpected elements in their lives. The sad part is, it's entirely possible not to witness ANY of these plot threads on your first playthrough, and there will undoubtedly be people who miss out on these awesome stories because they were unlucky enough to get a generic, predictable story on their first playthrough, which might turn them off to exploring relationships with the other birds. If you stick with it, and go back through the game seeking different outcomes, you will not be dissapointed. Hatoful Boyfriend is full of surprises, and you'll be rewarded for getting to know its twisted universe, and the characters within it. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I highly recommend this game. It definitely isn't for everyone, which is understandable given the ridiculous concept, but if you can get past that, there's some very memorable, touching, and hilarious moments just waiting to be discovered in this unexpected gem.

												With every single bit of seriousness my body can muster, out of every game I've played, this is genuinely one of the best written stories I have ever had the pleasure of playing through, PERIOD. Most people will look at this game, play through maybe one or two routes, write it off as "jokey birb game", and, unfortunately, never touch it again. Which sucks, considering the real meat of this game lies in the epilogue, where the genre does a complete 180. This game goes from animu-like dating sim with some hilarious parodies of a lot of visual novel tropes (with the exception of the Nageki route, which deals with some very heavy subjects), to a murder mystery full of twists and turns, with some surprisingly disturbing horror elements thrown in. There were at least three different points where I thought the game was about to end, but it just kept throwing more and more curveballs at me.The core game is full of wonderful silliness and knows what it is. The characters and their personalities are memorable and hilarious.Definitely a must-complete kind of game. Took me around 10 hours to go through every route and get the true ending. :)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Thirteen hours. Thirteen hours in less than three days I have logged into this game. Never have I been so drawn into pigeons.Like everyone else here, I was drawn in by the promise of a silly dating SIM involving birds. I didn't expect this game to be anything intensely amazing. So, when I began, though I had read plenty of reviews, I did not take too many of them that seriously. At first I wasn't overly impressed. The storyline itself seemed solid, though a bit vauge, and the choices that you are allowed in the game are relatively few. It's more a reading adventure than anything, and I quickly learned how to make each bird like me. However, the storyline wasn't nearly so well made as the reviews had spoken of. I had my favorites, of course, but the game seemed a little flat and lacking even at the deepest stories (my personal favorites are Nageki's and Sakuya's), and I disliked the lack of ability to interact with other birds while trying to woo a specific fowl.And then, though tenacity and determination, I got through all 14 endings, and everything changed.I won't say anything about the BBL ending. It needs to be played to be appreciated. But this story? This entire game is a work of art. I sat for three hours straight, playing the ending alone, just gaping at how well and perfectly everything fit together, with all the character interaction I had been missing and the complex storylines and depth that the game has been lauded for.This game is worth every penny.There are some technical difficulties I'm not impressed with. The save feature, for me, was a joke. Half the time the game would glitch and freeze when a save point was loaded, and made me have to go through and replay the game again. I saw the intro at least 12 times, which is more times than anyone needs to be introduced to each bird and can get sickeningly boring. The game also had a tendancy to freeze at important decisions, making me have to replay yet again, so it became a real effort in patience trying to deal with these glitches without throwing it out. All through the three hour ending, I was on the edge of my seat half expecting to have to go through most of it again because it might decide to freeze on me. Thankfully, it did not do any such thing, and I was able to enjoy myself through the massive and bright storyline *ehehe*. I also don't reccomend this game for those who are sensitive to gore and murder. Not because it shows any, because it doesn't, but some of these storylines get rather... descriptive of these things. I wouldn't say it's anything for kids, for sure.Even with these issues, if you're on the fence, tip over and fly. You won't regret it.~Kero

content:

												Warning: Possible SpoilersI didn't expect a bird dating sim (yes, you read that right) to make me have feelings in just the normal play throughs. As with other dating sims, you pick a character to pursue and follow the story with them. Each story had an ending (and some had a second, "extended" ending) and some were sweet, whereas others were... creepy. But all of them had some story that seemed to weave and connect together.Once you play through specific endings (though I'm not sure which ones they are, as I completed all the normal and extended endings first), you can start a new game which will lead you to an alternate ending. And man! The ramifications of that story! It takes a dark twist really fast, and just keeps leading you down the rabbit hole. But the amazing thing? All of the little story bits you've picked up throughout all the dating endings come to a close in the final story.This game is great. I cried a bunch. I laughed a bunch. I said "NO WAY!" a bunch. The way it all ties together was mind blowing. That so much forethought had gone into this silly bird dating sim to create something much more than that. There is also an Epilogue ending you can get if you have completed all of the prior endings, and it ties everything else up in a nice little bow, and makes you feel better about the outcome of things overall.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												I didn't know what I was getting into when I first purchased this game. I had heard good things about it, but I didn't know for absolute certain if I would like it. Don't get me wrong, I love visual novels, and I like birds, but a visual novel about romancing birds? That was something different.I went into the game not knowing what to expect. I came out of it completely in love with everything it had to offer.The storyline seems simple: you play as a girl who is entering an all-birds school as the only human. Your life as a high school student is determined by the choices you make, as well as who you choose to romance.The more I played the game and unlocked endings, the more I fell in love with the characters and their stories. Everyone in the game is more than what meets the eye, and are actually deep and well-developed (sans Okosan; he's just comic relief).The story, as simple as it seems, is actually really dark and heartbreaking, especially the "BBL Route". I won't spoil anything, but it caught me off-guard. Throughout the character routes, I actually found myself tearing up a bit. Nageki and Ryouta's routes come to mind when it comes to emotional storytelling.Overall, Hatoful Boyfriend is a game I can't recommend enough. It's funny, cute, and still manages to have a story you can take seriously even thought the cast is made up of birds. This game is worth the $10, but if you want to wait for the price to drop, go ahead. This isn't a game you want to miss out on.Pros-+ Funny and charming atmosphere in the beginning.+ Still manages to be taken seriously when things take a dark turn.+ A lovable cast of characters.+ It's one of the most unique visual novels I've played/read.Cons-- The looks on your confused friends' faces when they see this game in your library.- Having to explain to them why you bought the game in the first place.Recommended for:Bird fans, romance anime fans, and those looking for something different and refreshing.Rating:Buy / Wait / Burn?BUY

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Warning: Possible SpoilersI didn't expect a bird dating sim (yes, you read that right) to make me have feelings in just the normal play throughs. As with other dating sims, you pick a character to pursue and follow the story with them. Each story had an ending (and some had a second, "extended" ending) and some were sweet, whereas others were... creepy. But all of them had some story that seemed to weave and connect together.Once you play through specific endings (though I'm not sure which ones they are, as I completed all the normal and extended endings first), you can start a new game which will lead you to an alternate ending. And man! The ramifications of that story! It takes a dark twist really fast, and just keeps leading you down the rabbit hole. But the amazing thing? All of the little story bits you've picked up throughout all the dating endings come to a close in the final story.This game is great. I cried a bunch. I laughed a bunch. I said "NO WAY!" a bunch. The way it all ties together was mind blowing. That so much forethought had gone into this silly bird dating sim to create something much more than that. There is also an Epilogue ending you can get if you have completed all of the prior endings, and it ties everything else up in a nice little bow, and makes you feel better about the outcome of things overall.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												This game took me completely by surprise.Everything about Hatoful Boyfriend suggested that it wasn't anything more than a joke. I expected to play this game for an hour, show it to my friends, have a good laugh, and move on. What I didn't expect, was just how much this game would impact me on a deeper level.The story starts off slow, gradually introducing you to each bird. This is the part of the game where the concept is at its most ludicrous. Bird puns are thrown around with reckless enthusiasm, and you'd be forgiven for assuming that the rest of the story would follow in the same comedic vein. However, there's a much darker tale lying just beneath the surface. I don't want to spoil anything here, but suffice to say that these birds have issues. Tragic pasts, entertwining dramas, bleak outlooks, sinister plans, and a caveat of other unexpected elements in their lives. The sad part is, it's entirely possible not to witness ANY of these plot threads on your first playthrough, and there will undoubtedly be people who miss out on these awesome stories because they were unlucky enough to get a generic, predictable story on their first playthrough, which might turn them off to exploring relationships with the other birds. If you stick with it, and go back through the game seeking different outcomes, you will not be dissapointed. Hatoful Boyfriend is full of surprises, and you'll be rewarded for getting to know its twisted universe, and the characters within it. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I highly recommend this game. It definitely isn't for everyone, which is understandable given the ridiculous concept, but if you can get past that, there's some very memorable, touching, and hilarious moments just waiting to be discovered in this unexpected gem.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Hatoful Boyfriend isn't just the hilarious pigeon dating sim you see on the surface. Radical political parties, genocide, experimentation, biological warfare, murder, pudding--just to name a few--are all themes you'll encounter in this game.You are a human transfer student in a school specifically for birds. Unbeknownst to you, your mission is to woo every bird in the school, albeit one at a time in separate playthroughs. Each bird has different interests, personalities, and backstories, but the more you play, the more you'll realize that they're all intertwined, and that there's something terribly sinister going on at your school behind the scenes. Once you've seduced every bird and achieved every ending, you are rewarded with a chance to "fulfill the promise," and solve a mystery that will leave you on the edge of your seat for hours.Hatoful Boyfriend is beyond deceptive in its marketing as a joke, and I hadn't expected that it would tell a wonderfully written story that would leave me in tears at its end.--My only gripe about Hatoful Boyfriend is the spotty save system, as so many others seem to have issues with, too. I would occasionally need to load a save only to find that it would load a background without characters, text, or interface, forcing me to Alt+F4 to leave the game. The save file was forever corrupted, and I would have to restart that particular storyline. The dating playthroughs are short enough to finish in single sittings, but the finale can take hours to finish. I would recommend playing the finale only if you know you have a lot of free time ahead of you, at least until the save issues are fixed. I will amend this review should they be resolved.Oh, and the occasional typo or missing word, but that's not a big deal.--Have fun, everybirdie!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												This game is amazing. Admittedly, my experience with visual novels is a bit lacking (consisting mostly of Analogue: A Hate Story, Hate Plus, and various Twine games), but I have a feeling that Hatoful Boyfriend is probably not quite representative of a typical Japanese dating sim VN (and not just because of the birds).I don't want to spoil too much of the story, but it frequently veers pretty far off the beaten path. Japanese High school dating sim VNs have never really appealed to me too much as a general concept, but this game is much, much more than just a dating sim. The stories are wildly varied depending on your choices and what ending you're going for. There is thankfully a fast-forward button to get right to different choices to see how they play out, as well as ample save slots for saving before important choices.And I'd strongly recommend playing through every ending (don't be afraid to use a guide after your first playthrough). Each ending is interesting and varied on its own, but also because it unlocks a special epilogue story that's actually much longer than a normal playthrough. And the epilogue is definitely worth playing through - it gives a lot of background information on how the (evidently post-apocalyptic) society came about, and explains a lot of the backstories of the birds and the world you inhabit. It does drag on a bit near the end, but I'm really glad I played through to the end.If you like visual novels you'll love this game. If you don't like visual novels you'll still love this game because it's hilarious and weird and delightful. It certainly delivers a silly tongue-in-cheek bird dating parody, but it's so much more than that. Buy it.

TL;DR reviewWorth the money at half price (or better), but has several drawbacks that do not warrant a purchase at full price in my opinion. If you invest money into the game, be sure to reach the "BBL ending"; achieved through obtaining endings for all other routes. It makes the game a worthwhile investment, whilst the regular routes are poor at best.   Cons:The majority of the game grinding endings to get to the proper storyline ("BBL ending") is arduous, filled with ridiculous and often out-of-place dialogue that feels like it's pandering to the common internet idiot of today. Text is filled with "memes" and comical-at-best attempts at humour, with lavish and over-the-top hyperbole. Whether or not you "get" the references, you will be appalled at how hard the translators (and/or original story-writers, if the translations were properly adapted) try to fit them into as many situations as possible.   Pros• The inclusion of a 'fast-text' skip for the same scenes that will inevitably be repeated is a god-send; makes walking back through the game to achieve the alternate endings bearable.  • The final ending, and the story leading up to it (along with the glimmers of actual storyline in the shallow individual endings), is engrossing, and well worth the time to complete. The tone is different to that of the rest of the game, and justifies this as a purchase, if nothing else.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Oh dear, where do I start.Okay. This game was unreal. I thought I'd get a couple hours of goofing off with a bunch of pigeons and that it would be all fun and games and laughs and then I'd leave and play something more serious.Yeah...this game isn't just for sh**s and giggles. But there are many giggles. This game is as cute as it gets. You've got all these birds and they're all so different. At first glance you might think they're stereotypes come to life, but as it is with most people, there's more than meets the eye. Everybirdie has something special about them.I didn't even think I'd want to complete every single path, but sure enough I did. The BBL ending definitely gives you the most intriguing ending with lots of mystery and lots of Sakuya (eeeeee excuse me while I fangirl). I must admit my favourite endings were the more lighthearted ones though, the ones that were sweet and fluffy. And carve it into your soul, kid! There were many great endings. It's hard to pick a favourite.Also I thought Ryouta's path would be a bit more boring because he's the typical childhood-friend-turned-true-love kind of story everyone seems to love, but I think it was the most rewarding end.I really appreciate how the writer(s) approached topics like disability, status and even teacher crushes. There was never a point where I thought "Hmm, this seems inappropriate and harmful". Especially in a "dating sim" I even expected problematic moments, but there weren't any. I was overjoyed by that.WARNING: If you plan to do all the endings, this game does have its share of the violent and the gruesome. While you're not going to see blood and guts, trust me, some of the content in this game is very disturbing. There's murder (which I thought would give me nightmares nearly), suicide (which is dealt with quite respectfully) and probably other stuff I can't think of right now.For a so-called dating sim, this game isn't overly romantic. It feels more like a friendship sim than dating, to be perfectly honest. I loved that about this game. It surpassed every expectation.One complaint is the typos, specifically in the BBL ending. Way too many, and it made otherwise hard-hitting lines come off a little...underwhelming. But seriously, don't let that deter you. Just know that it's there, but that's one of my only real complaints.Lastly, I just want to mention the characters, who are all extremely rich and satisfying to learn about. I had a soft spot for Nageki, Ryouya, Sakuya and Yuuya. But surprisingly, the playable character is also super interesting as well! As you go through the endings, you learn about the bird of the hour but also quite a bit on who you're playing as too.Get. This. Game. Do yourself a service.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												An absolutely wonderful buy! An April Fool's day joke gone way too far in the best way possible."Quirky" is an excellent way to describe this game. At first glance, it's easily overlooked and labelled as 'too weird' and 'odd', but rest assured the game itself is much more fantastic than that. (Although, to be fair, the oddity is a part of its charm.) Go in with an open mind and it isn't hard to be sucked into this world and all its shenanigans.The re-release has updated the graphics beautifully and any fan of otome games with a good sense of humor is bound to love this game. The save option in the bottom right-hand corner makes it incredibly easy pause the game whenever necessary and pick up exactly where you left off without having to wait for a check-point or anything of the sort.The routes and birds are all very entertaining and lovable in their own ways. Nageki is my personal favorite and I fell in LOVE as soon as I saw him (  possibly loved him even more after I found out about his tragic backstory  ). They'll make you cry, laugh, scream, coo, and give you a reason to see each one of their endings. Luckily, it's not hard to achieve these endings either seeing as a mistake or two will still typically allow you to complete the route (with the exception of a few birds if you choose to get their "Best end" or "full end" routes).Another note worth mentioning is that the protagonist of this game is very well done! For most otome games, I personally find the protagonists to lack a little bit of personality and tend to be quite generic (this is usually due to the fact that the player's choices determine what the protagonist's personality is like) but with this game, there is no worry. Hiyoko (if you choose to maintain the default name) is as amusing as she is quirky, and her cheerful hunter-gatherer demeanor will work its way into your heart just as well as any of the other birds in the game while maintaining the ability to make personalized choices.If you enjoyed Hatoful Boyfriend and have not bought the DLC, then I suggest you go do so. The same goes for the holiday sequel, Hatoful Boyfriend: Holiday Star (which has extra content) and is a must-buy if you fell in love with the characters and their stories like I did.10/10 Would buy again. Would play again. Coo Coo!!!(  BBL lay waste to my heart...  )

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												"Ha, pigeons? How weird. Let's buy this game, just for fun." Most people say this before purchasing this game. I know. I did in 2012 when it first came out on another website. I bought the game and decided to go for the most familiar bird to me. The Mourning Dove, Nageki.  A young boy who died too young. He was put in a medical centre because of his weak immune system. He had a disease, the H5N1 virus. It was able to kill the humans that killed Nageki's family. However, he didn't want to kill the humans. He said he couldn't live anymore, so he threw himself into the fire he lit in the centre's basement.	 This game turned sad when I reached his ending. I decided to replay it, this time going for the fluffball of a partridge, Shuu, or shall I say  Isa Souma.	 His ending made this game much darker. I decided to play the rest of the game. After I played Ryouta's ending, a new choice popped up. I could fulfill a promise. I didn't know it at the time, but I wasn't Hiyoko when I made the choice. I was the Doctor. Shuu wanted to fulfill the promise he made to someone he loved. The game switched genres before my eyes. It went from a supposedly silly dating simulator to a horrifying murder mystery with pigeons. This game, while being amazing, has a few flaws, but they are quite small compared to the pros. The grammar isn't very good compared to some games, but what do you expect from a game translated into English from Japanese. There are also numerous plot holes that aren't solved unless you buy the sequel, Holiday Star. Like  why Hitori bleached his feathers. Most believe that it was to hide his true identity to get revenge on Shuu. While that is true, there is a second reason.Overall, this game is fantastic. It gets you hooked on the eerie and sad twists and then just makes a 360 turn into pigeon hell. There is no escaping now.Rating8 running Okosan's out of 10.

content:
Posted: February 28
												Bought it expecting lame puns and not much else. Seven hours later and I'm contemplating getting the DLC. How did this happen to me? How do you even review this game? Even without the bizarre premise, it isn't exactly your ordinary dating VN. Hatoful Boyfriend honestly deserves plaudits just for skirting the blender of meme-game shovelware with a setting like this, let alone producing a convincingly authentic VN with a twist.Let's get it out of the way. Yes, you are a human at a school for birds. The only human. You'd expect this to be handwaved and rarely referred to, right? Bzzzt, wrong. The plot is actually far deeper than anticipated; the real cherry atop this game is the BBL route at the end, which radically alters the tone and veers in a far darker direction than the main game. Themes include: murder, suicide, rejection, dystopia, genocide and human experimentation. Yeah. Seriously grim at times, it manages to combine Sherlock and Under the Dome in fleshing out the main cast far beyond where the main game takes them.Before all that, the main game is actually pretty pleasant. The...birds...are characterised surprisingly deftly, and avoiding the common VN pitfall of nailing one identifiable trait to a character and bludgeoning you over the head with it at every opportunity. These guys are genuinely sympathetic, and each route generally avoids too much repetition beyond the first semester. Your avatar is pretty funny, and seems to channeling her inner Mongol about half the time, as she studies in class and makes choices regarding the secret lives of birds. The foreshadowing for the final route is subtly done.Even if the Bad Boys Love route didn't exist, I'd still be rating this positively...it's a solid VN, funny and polished. The end route only elevates Hatoful Boyfriend considerably above most peers, and was a refreshing departure from the usual themes in dating sims. A murder-mystery whodunnit tacked onto a game about romancing pigeons - why not?

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												TL;DR: My favorite visual novel game, period. I consider it a must-play for VN/otome fans. ---Overall Impression: It took me awhile to get past, "Oh, Japan... dating birds?" to try it out. I had resolved I'd heard enough to give it a go, but it took watching Dodger's (presshearttocontinue) Let's Play to actually buy it. It made me laugh and it made me genuinely cry. It's probably best if you are familiar with otome game tropes, but a good background in anime/manga might do to pick up on all the jokes. Even if you only come at the game for the "weirdness", I hope you stay to see its real charm.Content: Don't get me wrong - Hatoful Boyfriend may be silly and weird and cute on the surface and once you dig past it, well, it's still silly and weird... But it also brushes along some really dark and heavy stuff. The list that follows will contain content spoilers, though if you have issues, it's better to have mild spoilers than be upset. SPOILERS: There is violence. Death - lots of death. War. Genocide. Murder (including of children). Suicide. Translation: I think the translation is fantastic. Editing: A few very minor issues, but overall, I had no complaints. I can't even remember any specific issues.Art: Let's get real here... there's really not a lot of "art" here! Unlike many VNs, there are no "event" CGs. Each character really gets one sprite with no changes of expression and the human portrait you see once if you turn on the human portrait option. In the end, it honestly adds to the absurdity, so I have no complaints. The backgrounds are pretty gorgeous, though. And the ending slates are really cute. The artist has done comics with the gang and sometimes does artwork of the characters, which she posts to her Tumblr and Deviantart accounts. If you want art, check those things out, because they're great!Story: On the surface, you're sold on, "Oh, Japan!" - just the absurd premise of a human girl going to a school for intelligent birds and falling in love with one of the birdie boyfriends available in typical "school romance" style. You dig a little deeper and you see the tropes being made fun of (gently, and with love).Then you start caring about these "dumb birds".Then you're hit with something heavy. If you get to the point of caring, it's pretty much guaranteed it'll hurt. The author skillfully manipulates you to this point and I admire her greatly for it.I honestly find myself at a loss to describe the story in any other way. I don't really see the birds as "bachelors to be wooed", though technically they are. They are, however, characters to fall in love with, and I do. I love every one of them, faults and all.The Heroine: She's kind of a meathead, honestly! (The creator also uses a cartoon piece of meat to represent her in the comics.) She's weird and maybe not entirely bright on the surface - but she's probably much smarter than she lets on. She definitely has a personality of her own! (She just has no official character design!) There's something subversive about her that the more I get to know her, the more I appreciate her.In closing... I really, really hope you pick it up. I enjoyed it enough I own the Collector's Edition (something I wouldn't necessarily recommend at full price unless you're already a fan - the comic and yearbook aren't that many pages). I also own all the comics and the sequel game, Holiday Star, from purchasing them from the creator's homepage. I'll also be purchasing a new copy of Holiday Star when it it comes to Steam. I'm a super fan! Complete with fanart! It's often on discount, but even at full price is cheap for such a great game.EDIT: Just adding that Holiday Star is out on Steam and I hope you pick it up too!

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												Hatoful Boyfriend is a game originally released in 2011 in Japan and has been rereleased globally in 2014 onto Steam.We have seen various dating simulators on Steam which have been pretty mediocre (not that I have played any of them...). However this game should be the No. 1 priority for Steam users if they are looking into immersing themselves in visual novels for the first time. Of course, users can play visual novels that are not on Steam such as Katawa Shoujo (which is exceptionally good by the way), but we should seize the opportunity Lord GabeN has given us, allowing us to play dating simulators on the legendary platform known as Steam. So don't lose this opportunity! Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel game in which the player dates pigeons. Although this may sound like an unusual concept, we gamers are always looking out on the market for the latest innovative games which bring new concepts and ideas to the congested video game market. Although the visual novel genre isn't especially innovative, the idea of having a romantic relationship between the protagonist, you, and various male pigeons is certainly innovative. Therefore I am giving this game a thumbs up.This may seem like a review just to laud the game's innovation and creativity. However, the gameplay and graphics are also up to par with the other releases which have come out at around the same time as this game. Even though this game is a visual novel, it provides immersive gameplay which will keep players like myself hooked on for hours at a time. The soundtrack for the game is one of the best in the market, which is why I purchased the Digital Deluxe version of the game, which includes the song's soundtrack! Positives   Exceptional graphics (Can be considered a benchmarking tool similar to what Ryse: Son of Rome was on PC).  Exceptional storyline (Not as good as Barbie Dreamhouse Party but still better than The Last of Us).  Exceptional optimization (Runs better than Assassin's Creed: Unity).  Exceptional gameplay (Combine Flappy Bird and Angry Birds).  Exceptional characters (Especially Okosan). Mixed   No nudity (Depends whether you like nude pigeons or not. If you do, I do not know if there is an uncensored version out there...). Negative   No anti-aliasing (I feel like the graphics could be even more amazing if there was some anti-aliasing).  Not enough pigeons (I need more to suppress my desires...).Even though this game has some negatives about it, I would still consider it to be GOTY. We all know there is no such thing as a perfect video game. The positives heavily outweigh the negatives and that is all that matters. So therefore, I hope that you have carefully read this review and will pick this game up as soon as possible. If you are not overly convinced that this game is amazing yet, I suggest reading the other 1,500 or so reviews on the store page!8/8(I hope you didn't expect this review to be legitimate XD)

Once you complete all 14 'normal' endings, you unlock the secret, ridiculously unsettling "BBL" route that explains everything and ties all the individual routes together, and THAT'S where it REALLY gets good.♥♥♥♥♥♥gets crazy. It's a game that goes beautifully from light humour, to dark humour, then just plain dark with no hesitation and so well written and paced that it will always leaves you at a loss for words. This was much more than I bargained for when I signed up for a silly dating game about pigeons in highschool.Although it starts kind of slow and repetitive (as most visual novels do), I strongly suggest you stick through the happy-go-weird-pigeon dating and go unlock that magnificently grotesque backstory - THAT'S the real deal. Of course, users can play visual novels that are not on Steam such as Katawa Shoujo (which is exceptionally good by the way), but we should seize the opportunity Lord GabeN has given us, allowing us to play dating simulators on the legendary platform known as Steam. So don't lose this opportunity! Hatoful Boyfriend is a visual novel game in which the player dates pigeons. Although this may sound like an unusual concept, we gamers are always looking out on the market for the latest innovative games which bring new concepts and ideas to the congested video game market. Although the visual novel genre isn't especially innovative, the idea of having a romantic relationship between the protagonist, you, and various male pigeons is certainly innovative. Therefore I am giving this game a thumbs up.This may seem like a review just to laud the game's innovation and creativity. However, the gameplay and graphics are also up to par with the other releases which have come out at around the same time as this game. Even though this game is a visual novel, it provides immersive gameplay which will keep players like myself hooked on for hours at a time. The soundtrack for the game is one of the best in the market, which is why I purchased the Digital Deluxe version of the game, which includes the song's soundtrack! Positives   Exceptional graphics (Can be considered a benchmarking tool similar to what Ryse: Son of Rome was on PC).  Exceptional storyline (Not as good as Barbie Dreamhouse Party but still better than The Last of Us).  Exceptional optimization (Runs better than Assassin's Creed: Unity).  Exceptional gameplay (Combine Flappy Bird and Angry Birds).  Exceptional characters (Especially Okosan). Mixed   No nudity (Depends whether you like nude pigeons or not. If you do, I do not know if there is an uncensored version out there...). Negative   No anti-aliasing (I feel like the graphics could be even more amazing if there was some anti-aliasing).  Not enough pigeons (I need more to suppress my desires...).Even though this game has some negatives about it, I would still consider it to be GOTY. We all know there is no such thing as a perfect video game. The positives heavily outweigh the negatives and that is all that matters. So therefore, I hope that you have carefully read this review and will pick this game up as soon as possible. If you are not overly convinced that this game is amazing yet, I suggest reading the other 1,500 or so reviews on the store page!8/8(I hope you didn't expect this review to be legitimate XD)

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Hatoful Boyfriend is the visual novel that got me to start reading visual novels a few years ago, and along with Katawa Shoujo, showed me how genuinely well written they can be. With the absurd premise of dating talking, oversized birds in a high school called St. Pigeonation's, you'd be forgiven for assuming that game was entirely parodical. Yet the stories of characters such as Nageki and Ryouta become genuine tearjerkers towards their conclusions, and the game gradually unlocks more sinister stories as you go, with Iwamine Shuu's being the darkest of all normal routes by far, with some very creepy overtones and disturbing implications. Then you complete enough routes to unlock the "Bad Boys Love" (I have no idea why it was called this) mode, which is incredibly difficult to discuss without massive spoilers, but what I can tell you is that not only does its own story go to very dark places, but it gives every other route far darker implications in retrospect. Hatoful Boyfriend's sequel, "Holiday Star", was released awhile back on DLSite, and is not a dating sim in any respect. Its main story is almost entirely linear, but it is hilarious and absurd, featuring such nonsense as fangirl powered cannons. Like the original game, its story gets much darker later on. It also dials back the dating sim elements to unlockable extra scenes that are accessed through the main menu. If you can enjoy, or even just get past, the premise of this game, then I wholeheartedly recommend it, because the worst it can be is a cheap laugh. If you give it a chance, you'll find that it's far more than that. In addition, the Steam release upgrades the game to 1080p with some very nice, crisp artwork - although the bird pictures look even more out of place now - and adds some additional content in the form of a route for the awesome Azami. Its Collector's Edition is also a good deal with 2 silly wallpapers, the soundtrack, a copy of the original DLSite version of the game, a Hatoful Boyfriend manga and a "yearbook" artbook of the game.
