content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I flew into this completely blind. I had heard of its existence some time ago, could not figure out how to get the stupid English patch I downloaded to work, and ended up shelving it before more-or-less forgetting about it completely.Recently, however, it showed up for 75% off during the summer sale. This, combined with my now-twice piqued interest meant it was added to my cart instantly. I am not dissapointed.I will preface this by stating that this isn't much of a game, so if you were expecting plenty of action and mashing of buttons, you are sorely mistaken. It's more of a semi-interactive novel, not all that far from a "choose your own adventure" book. You start off,  quite simply, as a teenaged human girl attending a school for birds (because what else would you expect?). The opening presents you with a run-down of the various relevant figures of your school. Every one of these has their own storyline that you can progress through by taking actions or making decisions favoring them. At the end, you get a unique ending specific to that character. You may also be presented with the "bad" ending if you somehow fail to endear yourself to any particular bird, though, with one exception, it's not really too hard to figure out what you need to do to charm your feathered fiancee.And that's it. You now know how to "play" Hatoful Boyfriend.That may seem like I'm cutting it a bit short, but I fear that getting any more in-depth about plot points is essentially impossible without spoiling one thing or another, especially in regards to a certain event that becomes available once you've received enough of the endings (yes, you do have to "date" Shuu). Very much of the game's appeal lies in the fact that it goes from exactly what the description implies (a silly, lighthearted title centered around dating pigeons), to a rather engrossing and intriguing story about how this odd world works. Moreover, there's little to say outside of "it's a thing where you read a lot of text and occasionally make a decision". That's not necessarily bad, but this isn't going to be something that appeals to you if you aren't the kind who enjoys an honest-to-god book every now and again.Hatoful Boyfriend is not a purchase I regret, but it's not without its flaws. The most glaring is that much of the text is repeated, between storylines. There's a fast-forward button that will rapidly skip through text, however some scenes have the same beginning but diverge from there, meaning you might accidentally skip some dialogue you haven't read yet with this. A moderate familiarity with how the game goes helps prevent this, but that takes a few playthroughs and still isn't foolproof.There are relatively few blemishes beyond that, and they're relatively minor, luckily enough. There are a few typos, although only one of them is major (you still get the gist of what's being said). There are some odd "between" frames of dialogue that are blank and require you to press the enter key, but there's no indication you need to do so other than that nothing is happening. The "level/stats" system is almost completely pointless, and I think is only really there for a few very specific scenes which probably could have got by without it anyway.The redundant text is problematic, but it's not game breaking and the other downsides can mostly be overlooked. I question the price point of $10 full price, seeing as how there isn't any way to spend that much meaningful time on the game. I read fairly fast, and have essentially completed the game in well under 10 hours. Slower readers could reasonably expect somewhat longer than that. At sale price, especially as steep a sale as I got it on, it is well worth it.I mean...come on you guys it's a pigeon dating sim. If that doesn't at least get you curious enough to skip out on your next bag of chips to shell out for it, you are sad, and I have no desire to associate with you any further than I already have. Also I just realized what I did with that opening sentence. I am sorry, I swear that was not intentional.I'm not deleting it, though.The "too long/didn't read" section:Pros:-It's a dating sim with pigeons-Decent visuals-Interesting reading-No actual bird sexCons:-Not really a "game", per se-Relatively short-Reduntant text-Some small technical issues-No actual bird sexFinal thoughts: If it's on sale and you like to read, don't even give it a second thought; "Carve it into your soul, kid!"

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												~~WARNING, THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS, IF YOU DONT WANT THE GREATEST DATING SIM OF ALL TIME SPOILED, DON'T READ THIS~~I first played this game a while ago, on its first English release. I believe that was over 3 years ago now? When I originally heard of this game, I of course reacted like everyone else. "Wow, absurd crazy Japanese dating sim about... birds??? This is so ridiculous that I have to play it."A big thing that completely goes over peoples' heads, a conclusion they never seem to come to when they see this game in the Steam store, or when they saw it online wherever for the first time is... could this possibly be tongue-in-cheek? You know, a parody of generic Dating Sim/Visual Novel tropes? Which is kind of crazy to be honest, considering that's what immediately should be coming to their mind - that yes, this game parodies a lot of silly Visual Novels that take themselves far too seriously.The first portion of this game, the "normal high school life" routes, a lot of them use very cliché anime/RPG/Dating Sim tropes, particularly Okosan's slice-of-life, non-serious route, Shuu's sort of yandere true ending, and Anghel's downright crazy and completely non-canon route (is it technically non-canon, considering the effect Anghel causes upon those around him?), but they're written in such a self-aware way, a lot of these storylines know fully well how ridiculous they are and they're not ashamed to be so.A lot of the routes do give a bit of insight into each of the characters and you can start to piece things together, but the bulk of the actual plot comes in final route, the Bad Boys Love ending. Hatoful Boyfriend is not a dating sim. The Dating Sim section, in my opinion, was simply a very clever selling point of the game. It is essentially used as such because the devlopers KNEW people would buy something so out there, and for shock value. When you start to realise truly how dark this game is, it's genuinely shocking.If this game was depicted as a serious visual novel about a political faction with extreme racist views, and their goal to rid Earth of the opposing race through means of biological weaponry, even if that requires unethical treatment of their own kind, this game would have been critically acclaimed. Which is funny, because that's EXACTLY what this game is about. There's a lot more to it than that, but that's the basic plot.Albeit the writing is a bit goofy at times, even in serious parts, and there's a lot of unnecessary gore, this game is extremely cleverly written. Despite disguising itself as a dating sim at first glance, and being a mockery to those who haven't played it, this game has pretty interesting politIcal undertones and social commentary, and honestly? I'm awfully more attached to talking birds than I was to any of the characters in westerm, artsy, "plot heavy" (but not really) indie games on Steam such as Thomas Was Alone.But yeah, I'd love to give Hatoful Boyfriend a 10/10 for how well marketed and well put together this game is, along with its amazingly witty writing, but I have to give it a 9.5 for being unnecessarily, I guess, "edgy" and fanfiction-esque at times.P.S. I've very tempted to figure out a way of rewriting the entire script of this game to be... well, not about birds, and sending it to my friends not telling them what it is. And I can guarantee they'd never be able to guess

I found this game with pigeons...' and it's better than the usually weird porn I talk about because it's socially accepted and not rated R. Anyway, I started it and I was (positively) destroyed by little details like 'everybierdie' and so on. I chose the easiest route and I already forgot I was talking about pigeons. I mean, their image was still there, all pigeony, but I knew they were more than that. I felt it in my kokoro. The final shattered me: oh boy, I was so much unprepared! I finished the rest of the routes in like an afternoon??? And it was always getting better and I still don't know how it this possible. Then, the true ending, is just the epiphany of pure genius. I cried, I was overwhelmed by feelings and, idk, stuff. The end destroyed everything I always believed in and now I know I'll never reach that level of utter perfection.graphic9/10; I played it in fast mode, so the graphic wasn't the best, but still is pretty good for an otome game! The human portraits are just 100% boyfriend material (I dare you to pick your favv among them) and the background are really relaxing. Bonus points to the random photos of birds, like the Brian ones that looks like a pigeon itself took them and I love it. plot10/10; I have no words to say how good is the plot. I read a lot, I love cinema, I love every kind of media that bring me new stories, but this is♥♥♥♥♥♥of a different level. Guys, this plot is deep as ♥♥♥♥ and it's weird, and wrong and utter genius.setting & originality10/10; During the standard routes you catch a few hints of the backstory but you'll be surprised anyway. The whole basic idea is so weird you'll just go 'why not???' and it makes sense in the end. At least for you. No one will believe you anymore, but it will make sense. It is a story that talks to the heart, not to the mind, but still is a complete experience that will change you. Please, buy this game, because it is worth every cent of it. 												It's a pretty standard visual novel, with all the feelings and emotional attachments, relatively quick not very involved....Oh and you're seducing birds.The game was originally created as a joke, but was so popular that the creator and developers released it on multiple platforms, because the only thing to brighten some of the deep feelings you have from trying to get that special someone to notice you is to turn everyone except for you into a bird.If visual novels are your thing, this is a ridiculous game that is well worth your time and energy.  If they aren't quite your thing, you will probably be confused.  This game is still ridiculous, and a fun way to get introduced into the genre, without having to deal with actual humans. It really is just as ridiculous as it looks, and that's half the fun. The other half is trying to figure out how anyone would allow the school doctor near students.  Let alone set him as a romance option.  You'll laugh, you'll stare confused at the screen, you'll laugh some more, you might find yourself attached to a birdie character. And that's okay.  Because it's fun, and funny, and no one talks about why you're the only human in the game.

Posted: July 18, 2016
												First of all, don't judge a book by its cover.I played through this game mostly because it was on sale.  But after playing it to full completion...I am utterly surprised that I actually enjoyed it.I'm not spoiling anything, but this is a game worth completing fully.  There IS actually a legit story and it isn't all rainbows and smiles.NO.  OH HECK NO.It isn't just a dating sim with birds, it can get twisted.  Scratch that, it WILL get twisted.I really encourage getting this game.  It's great all around.  Sure, the stories for each character a relatively short, but you will get to know a lot about them.  And it's worth it to get all the endings each character can give you.  Yes, even the incomplete endings.If you get all endings, the game gifts you with a lovely true ending that will send you on a roller coaster of emotions.  And some new emotions that you probably don't experience with many of the bachelors...except one.My only problem is that there is a fast forward option that will often skip over new scenes if you're not expecting it.  Some routes will add new pieces of dialogue to scenes you may have seen many times before, but if you don't know when they appear, the fast-forward option will just keep going.  Some games like this will stop for you when theres a new string of dialogue or take away the option to tell you that there's something new.  Not this game.Be warned!  The story is fantastic and you'll want to read every bit of it.It's strange, but I grew to like it!  Besides, the human versions of the birds you date are kind of cute.  :)

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Hatoful Boyfriend is the visual novel that got me to start reading visual novels a few years ago, and along with Katawa Shoujo, showed me how genuinely well written they can be. With the absurd premise of dating talking, oversized birds in a high school called St. Pigeonation's, you'd be forgiven for assuming that game was entirely parodical. Yet the stories of characters such as Nageki and Ryouta become genuine tearjerkers towards their conclusions, and the game gradually unlocks more sinister stories as you go, with Iwamine Shuu's being the darkest of all normal routes by far, with some very creepy overtones and disturbing implications. Then you complete enough routes to unlock the "Bad Boys Love" (I have no idea why it was called this) mode, which is incredibly difficult to discuss without massive spoilers, but what I can tell you is that not only does its own story go to very dark places, but it gives every other route far darker implications in retrospect. Hatoful Boyfriend's sequel, "Holiday Star", was released awhile back on DLSite, and is not a dating sim in any respect. Its main story is almost entirely linear, but it is hilarious and absurd, featuring such nonsense as fangirl powered cannons. Like the original game, its story gets much darker later on. It also dials back the dating sim elements to unlockable extra scenes that are accessed through the main menu. If you can enjoy, or even just get past, the premise of this game, then I wholeheartedly recommend it, because the worst it can be is a cheap laugh. If you give it a chance, you'll find that it's far more than that. In addition, the Steam release upgrades the game to 1080p with some very nice, crisp artwork - although the bird pictures look even more out of place now - and adds some additional content in the form of a route for the awesome Azami. Its Collector's Edition is also a good deal with 2 silly wallpapers, the soundtrack, a copy of the original DLSite version of the game, a Hatoful Boyfriend manga and a "yearbook" artbook of the game.

												There was one pigeon, a beautiful bird, pure white with light grey tips on its wings; that one was different. It was a male. I would know that pigeon anywhere. No matter where I was that pigeon would find me, when I wanted him I had only to wish and call him and he would come flying to me. he understood me and I understood him. I loved that pigeon. Yes, I loved him as a man loves a woman, and he loved me. When he was ill I knew, and understood; he came to my room and I stayed beside him for days. I nursed him back to health. That pigeon was the joy of my life. If he needed me, nothing else mattered. As long as I had him, there was a purpose in my life. Hatoful Boyfriend is a rewarding game that uses a friendly approach and healthy humour to apply great lessons useful to anyone longing to live in harmony with their loved ones, it can be anything from a  pigeon, human, ship, airfriend or even a rock. A game that can make you think about what is in front of you and about standing for what you believe in before you lose everything you have. It has indeed a spicy price for it's short play time but, if you're used to this kind of game and want to try to find some meaning on it by yourself, you should get it if you can.-My humble thanks to the staff behind this work, Nikola Tesla for the short story seen above (which is incomplete) and the dear friend who gifted me this game to sink my broken soul in a abyss of despair. Thank you, bird ♥♥♥♥erI knew she wanted to tell me- she was dying. When that pigeon died, something went out of my life. Up to that time I knew with a certainty that I would complete my work, no matter how ambitious my program, but when that something went out of my life I knew my life's work was finished.sucks

												Place chicken in a Dutch oven. Add water, carrot, celery, onion, 3 sprigs of thyme, and bay leaf. Bring to a boil, cover, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 1 hour. Remove chicken from dutch oven and transfer to a bowl; set aside to cool.Increase heat and bring the stock to a simmer. Skim off any chicken fat that appears on top of the stock and reserve in a bowl. Combine 2 to 3 tablespoons of the reserved fat with flour in a small bowl; stir to make a paste, adding more flour if needed. Add the chicken fat and flour mixture to the stock. Reduce heat and simmer for 15 minutes.Remove chicken meat from the carcass and add to the stock. Season with salt, black pepper, and cayenne pepper to taste. Continue simmering for 10 to 15 minutes.Whisk creme fraiche, milk, 2 teaspoons of thyme leaves, and eggs together in a large bowl. Stir in self-rising flour until almost entirely incorporated; do not overmix.Scoop large dollops of dumpling mixture on top of the chicken stock. Increase heat slightly to medium-high. Cover and simmer until dumplings appear light and fluffy, and a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean, 10 to 15 minutes. Serve garnish with thyme sprigs.

Posted: May 26, 2016
												First of all, don't trust the 'average' review score - the topic of this particular game (pigeon dating) has attracted droves of people trying to be funny with one line review quips.Simply speaking, the positive rating has me very very very confused because this is a terrible VN for the price.Story aside, there are some major issues with the game itself:1) "Maximum text speed" actually means "scrolls a bit faster" so you need to click twice to clear every message if you are a decent reader. Extremely annoying.2) No setting to skip only scenes you haven't watched. You either skip or you don't, and if you miss new content too bad. This is made worse by how some of the endings are very similar (ie, basically the same ending except for an epilogue) but you need to replay the entire game, not knowing if there are new nuggets in the game. 3) Loading glitches, many times when I loaded it would not work and just show an empty text box. Needed to exit to title and load that way.Main problems with the plot/art:1) If you are like me, part of the allure of VNs is looking at some cool anime characters. This game has virtually none of that. The teaser shots you see at the top of the store page are basically all there is, the rest of the "art" you can find by going to google and searching for "pigeon." Maybe spend some effort drawing characters in different poses? Nope, just the same cropped pigeon picture from google. In certain parts you may be lucky and get uncropped pigeon pictures when the game devs were lazy.2) There is a severe lack of development for all birds. It is not that uncommon, but "the bachelor syndrome" of going on 2 dates and falling in love forever for no apparent reason is alive and well. As such, the birds are super one-dimensional, from the mentally challenged pudding bird to the psycho daydreaming bird - they just rehash the same joke over and over, not changing or developing other sides to the birds at all.3) To build on #2, the game is generally not funny. A couple jokes initially could elicit a chuckle, but the joke rehash gets very tiring. As this game is a quasi-parody of dating sims, I don't think that's a good thing.4) The relationship scoring system is at best hidden, at worst useless. This is one of those games where the relationship stat is hidden and you need to guess where you stand with everyone. One of the major systems, where you pick your classes, is 100% useless in over half the endings.5) True ending - without using spoilers, this game tries to tie everything together in a grand true ending that answers all questions. You want to know why pigeons talk? Why there is a school for pigeons? The ending tells you! However, because the premise is so preposterous, the game just throws twist after twist at you, all of which are not coherent. From daddy issues to orphanages to secret agents, the game throws all the stereotypical tropes you could possibly dream up in one jumbled mess. To be fair, the ending does actually flesh out the characters somewhat and probably takes a solid couple hours to get through. Of course the content in the true ending is probably more than the content in the rest of the game combined, see #2.Long review for me as I rarely disagree so much with popular opinion. Bottom line is that I would NOT recommend this game unless it was 90% off or something, it is simply a poor example of a VN. Of course if you want to write a one line quip of a pigeon dating sim then you have no choice?

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This was, very unexpectedly, a really awesome game. I first started playing expecting a hilarious and absurd story just for the fun of it, but the game really sucked me in and kept me fascinated. Hell, I even bonded emotionally with the birds (especially those with more heartbreaking endings). The bonus ending (the BBL route) was one of the more compelling game (and VN) stories I remember reading made from such seemingly simple and ridiculous premises. I don't even know how they made all the story parts so intervowen, when at first they seemed so random. It was worth unlocking all the slightly repetitive playthroughs to get to it. For anyone wondering why this game is interesting - wait until you get to the last part.I'd recommend it to anyone who lacks prejudice against the obvious ridiculousness of the game and wants to try someting different. It's really funny, sad, and awesome all at the same time.

												Absoultuely my most favorite game in a very long time, the soundtrack is great, the visulatization is great, and the story is just beautiful. When you first see it you think: "Werid Japenese Pigeon Dating Simulator!", but when you get into the game it's just awesome! I'm very glad that this game has been remastered and put on Steam, I was oringally going to buy the orinigal version, but then I heard of the remastered version and I was like "Here's my money!"I'd give this game a 9.5/10:Pros: great story, heartwarming characters, beautiful soundtrack, birdy puns, rememerable characters, the idea that Okosan is awesome everytime you Hear "pudding", plus there's manga sidestories (that are on Amazon!)Cons: too short, text misspellings and grammar issues here and there, and too many people say "Ugh! Weird Japenese dating sim!"Either way, this game is awesome, I recommend everyone to buy the collectors edition for $15, trust me, you won't regret it.

Posted: May 9, 2016
												This game starts out as a normal dating sim. (Well as normal as you can get when you date an all pigeon cast.) You date all the birds, get all the endings. Pretty run of the mill for a dating sim. But then the game comes out and asks you to fulfill a promise. This is the BBL ending, or Bad Boy's Love. This is when the game switches from Otome dating sim to murder mystery psycological horror. I won't spoil it, but if thought some of the normal endings were dark, this blows them right out of the water. The characters develop greatly during the course of BBL and many questions are answered, so its worth playing however.I would greatly recommend this to any visual novel fan and also would be a great starting point to people wanting to get into the series. It has a suprising amount of depth for a game like this and shouldn't be taken at face value. So yeah. Buy it.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												Hatoful Boyfriend is a joy: it's fun, brief, and doesn't take itself too seriously. Its embrace of the absurd was a refreshing break from standard dating sim fare.Storywise, underneath the lighthearted, ridiculous exterior, there's a lot more to the plot and the world of Hatoful Boyfriend than meets the eye. My first playthrough was amusing, but as I played again to get more endings, more details about the game's overarching story were revealed. Making new discoveries about the plot became genuinely rewarding, and by the time I got all the endings it felt like a whole different game. As far as gameplay goes there's not much to say; it's purely a dating sim. The best part of the interface was the skip button, which makes replays take 5-10 minutes max instead of 30 minutes. Overall a fun game with great replay value, would recommend to anyone who likes dating sims, visual novels, and surreal games.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												It was cute and interesting for about an hour or so.It was after this point that I realized everything seems to end the same no matter what I do, the game forces you into select decisions otherwise the game abruptly ends and you can do nothing to stop it.It was good for a few brief chuckles, before the reality that the game is a decension into an unavoidable trajedy, woe is the target goal, success is only for those following a blind selection of options. Learnign from your mistakes is hard, because the cause of said trajedy often has no hints, such as your own death, is determined simply by what kinds of beans you buy at a store.That being said, if you want a brief chuckle, and do not want to take it seriously, you will probably few a few short hours of enjoyment.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------After playing it again, it has some nicer endings, neat plot twists at times, although it really does end very quickly each time no matter what. It's very funny and has a bit of wit to it, I don't like the price tag for how short it is, but its definately replayable, so I will give it a thumbs up, but I would look for it on sale.Special thanks to "Birds are cool" for gifting me this and letting me try it.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Palyed through most endings now. If you approach this as a game, you might be disappointed, however as a story that just has a few minor interactions and some pictures, with a few funny refrences and easter eggs here and there, it is a deep interwoven story that provides a few hours of entertainment easily.7.2/10

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												My friend bought this game for me, presumably as a joke, and I went along with it, of course. I played and got to know the characters, choosing which one to focus on with each game. Not only was I pleasently surprised with the depth of some of these characters, but I was also manipulated to feel an array of other emotions which, with a game like this, I would never expect to feel. Their stories made me feel heartbroken, happy and even sick. A game that is good will make me feel emotions intentionally and will have me hooked like this.Now, I am not usually ones for visual novels or games like this, however, the amount of love put in to this game, whether it was for a joke or not, is really something. The puns, the emotion, the references - they all balance out and you don't feel like you're being drowned by anything.Then there's the BBL. After completing some of the stories, you'll get the option to do this other story. After playing normally for a bit, you'll then see it from Ryouta's view. It was tense and I loved it. I won't say anything else.Thanks for buying this for me, Luke.

Well, you ain't gonna get none of that here.Now if you are still here, let me ask you another question: do you want to experience a wacky, surreal, snarky, comedic and touching tale? Well, you've got one here!Yes, the game has a girl dating pigeons; and no, there is no nudity nor lewd scene nor hentai of any sorts.Yes, the author did use pigeon pictures because she wasn't in the financial state of using animu characters;and no, you cannot swap just the characters with animu-cutouts; Moa Hato had worked the pigeon angle into the story.Yes, to many this isn't even a video game.and no, steam is no longer for video games only store, and you can be entertained by just reading a graphic novel.Yes, it's $10;and no, even if it were a 200 pages graphic novel it weren't over-priced.This is a refreshing, if not innovative idea; the story takes the pigeons theme with just the right among of silliness and seriousness. It's a surprisingly well written story based on oh-so-many clichés, yet is still able to take you completely by surprise.

Posted: December 31, 2014
												Hatoful Boyfriend is a fun spin on traditional otome visual novels. Of course, that much is obvious from the very premise of the game: a dating sim involving pigeons! What really made Hatoful for me was how weird and/or creepy a lot of the endings were, especially the "true ending" in the form of the "Bad Boys' Love"/Hurtful Boyfriend path that you unlock after achieving certain normal endings. I never expected to get this freaked-out by a game about dating pigeons! And on the happier side, Okosan's and Anghel's routes are amusingly weird, each in their own way. Still, some of the standard routes - including Ryouta's, Kazuaki's and Sakuya's, ones you need to achieve the BBL ending - are typical otome game stuff and don't have much to offer beyond that. But they're worth suffering through to get to the quality routes and to learn more about Hatoful's distinctive post-apocalyptic world. Give it a whirl even if you're not a VN fan.

content:
Posted: January 23
												Since this is on a game site, I am rating this as a game. The first playthrough...actually the first SEVERAL playthroughs I could not even get through this. The main reason I bought this was because of how much fun I had with the similar looking "Long Live The Queen". But this isn't much like that at all. Once I committed to the story and had more petience I did make it through, reading everything. There just is barely any game here. I see this touted as a visual novel....well there really isn't much story either. Dialogue is so generic. It's mostly a lot of awkward pauses and people being rude to your character. Reminds me of your most people play tabletop roleplaying games and what they say to NPCs when they do. The stats you have and build on....don't seem to do anything. You get to select what class you are taking as an elective a lot and each time that choice determines which of 3 stats go up (unlike the 18 that LLTQ has), But your stats really don't do anything. They need to DO something. THe elective choice really determines who you spend more time with. As each of the other characters in this seem to ONLY spend time in one place the entire game....thus making the world seem unrealistic. I like that you CAN steer yourself toward relationships with certain people and that is easy enough to do. After one playthrough I got the hang of the goal...."end up with someone". But a lot of time that goal isn't actually finished. BUt at least they wrote an ending for each person and that is satisfying. And your choices DO have effects on other characters. That too is rewarding. But there really needs to be much more of a story. More weaving and intertwining of characters. Since there really is no gameplay there needs to be more goals. Other games add collection type of goals...like Batman even amidst the fighting, has riddles to solve and question marks to collect and plenty of achievements to do. This game needed more achievements and other little things to accomplish on a meta level to go along with the story and that would have easily produced more ideas for sidecontent. But as is almost all of the achievements are which endings you get...aka who you end up with at the end.The bizarre idea of being at an all-bird school as a human is just so weird but cool and makes wyou want to just start dating birds. But that part of it is really underwhelming. The biggest problem is that almost all of the birds are white. So it's like...oh who's that bird? isn't that the other one? Haven't I met him before? Oh wait this is someone else. Is this a woman or a man? I have no idea. I thought my roommate was a girl. YOU CAN'T TELL! IT'S A BIRD.  Making things more complicated is that it uses all Japanese names. Why? It had no reason to. Maybe if the whole bird idea was dropped and it was just a human dating sim story, but there really is no reason for that. Because having Japanese names mames it harder to distinguish if it is a boy or a girl (I almost typed bird or a girl). I guess that's just picky since it is FOR anime fans so I could let that slide but it does complicate matters. The other thing that completely subverts the whooole bird idea is that it provides the option of giving you a portrait of each bird AS A HUMAN. It does this when you meet each one. WHY DOES IT DO THIS? This completely ruins the immersion of being in an allbird school. Why bother with birds then? The thing is....the dating birds thing is the ONLY hook this game has and then it ruins it with that idea. And even while it is breaking the bird immersion it does it poorly because not only do most of the birds appear white but their human potraits look mostly the same too. Thin anime characters with different colored hair. I only used that feature once and never again because it was so wrong for the story and the game.I did like the characters and their simple stories. I wanted more from ALL of them. If you are going to make a dating sim...why not allow you to go on MORE THAN ONE DATE. Why not let you date multiple people. It's like once you go on one date, then you find out a brooding secret about each person and then that's the end. And therein lies the only actual satisfaction. Trying to get each ending. And it is fast enough to play through the entire game very quickly until you get to a part you haven't seen before. And this is the best gameplay feature. With the simple click of the mouse button (or keyboard type), you can skip through the current bit of dialogue that's scrolling on the screen. That is SO IMPORTANT. Great. So just multiple click through the parts you've seen before! Hold on! there's an even BETTER button. They have a fast forward button! Click it and it zooms through whole sections until you have to make a choice or until it reaches a new chapter. That is so WONDERFUL. They need to use this format to make another much longer and more intricate story because that gameplay suits this kind of game perfectly. However, the amount that it actually has to skip before you get to even your FIRST choice is VERY VERY telling on how few choices you actually have.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												this game LOLseriously.COO COO Recommended.EDIT: WOW. This minx of a game is hiding the REAL game inside of it - the BBL ending. Once you've unlocked an ending for each character, you can choose to 'fulfil the promise' and then your opinion of the game can't help but expand. What happens next is a murder mystery of reasonable predictability but with 1 or 2 surprising twists and an ending with plenty of room for a sequel. The character development really opens up in this mode, and we at last see all the pieces fall into place.On the whole, the game is full of comedic zaniness which makes it quite difficult to take seriously but charming in its execution. There's a lot to take in for players who don't like to read, and it does have a flair of the quintessential anime-plot quality (tonnes of expose that gets dished out in huge bursts nearer and nearer the end) which doesn't appeal to everyone, but it's enjoyable on the whole, even if it contains not-so-subtle self-referential advertising at one point lolIt's a lot to take in, but it's worth a look, especially if it's for sale on offer during a sale!!

												There is alot more to this game than meets the eye. However as not to spoil anything too much I will say that the story is well written, memorable and sometimes very humorous, there are some cliche moments but the overall experience is a great one. Be prepared for a ride full of emotion and deep plot.This game really goes to show that even something as silly as talking birds can be made clever and deep with well enough writing.If you do plan on getting this diamond in the rough then I recommend you get every ending to fully experience everything the game has to offer. "Carve it into your soul kid!"TL:DR 8.5/10 Well developted story that has much more to offer then it seems.Some Information to answer possible questions-A single ending is roughly 20-30 minutes-All endings totaled should be about 8.5 hours-You can save at any point.(useful for getting multiple endings)-Human portraits are optional and will only appear once per playthrough(during character introductions)

												Hatoful Boyfriend is a wonderfully bizzare RPG/Dating sim game, Not one normally for the Dating RPG genre I picked this up during the summer sale and was very plesently surprised it's quite different from the usual plod, with 13 different endings and a 14th "Final end" ending, the main 13 range from the utterly obsurd to actually quite moving which I thought was a nice touch and really added range to what felt possible in game, it's quite wittily written at times though the amount of Egg and Bird Puns does begin to wear a bit around about the 7th or 8th playthrough...its a pretty solid build of a game with my only gripe being the 14th ending known as the "BBL" ending. your milage may vary on it. but you'll either see it as A wonderful Amplifier that greatly adds depth and further character to what on the surface is a fairly light hearted game. or a very over played bloated add on to  the game that only seems to add a small book of texts worth of story with little to no choice in the matter... content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												A cute game with an interesting premise that unfortunately doesn't subvert the genre enough to make it not feel like an actual dating-sim.Dating sims are one of those really untouchable games for me, I think they are dumb, weird and creepy. Yet, Hatoful Boyfriend seemed like it was going to really appeal to the masses through a bit of satire, parody and commentary. I guess it does do that in a way, if not much, which is probably why it's had a radiating but mild success in other demographics. But I expected more, like some more gameplay, or branching interactions to really throw the competitors of the genre in the mud since they rely only on horrible anime pseudo porn. If it were to be a great parody AND to also include some legit gameplay, animations or more story depth and length, to really show others how to really make an interesting 'dating' sim at the same time would have elevated it to a great GAME, not some cheap feeling visual novella with around 10 input screens. Hatoful Boyfriend on the surface seems to only jest at the dialog of the genre in a very absurd  'lol dating games amirite?!' sort of way. Sure, some of the writing is silly, a bit fun, sometimes humorous and sometimes dark. But that's all you get, it still feels like i'm just playing an odd dating simulator after a few playthroughs.  Call me crazy but if there was a hint of a descent into madness, I would have liked to have seen a glimpse of it within the first hour of playing so I would be enticed to keep on digging deeper.Maybe I was expecting something along the lines of The Stanley Parable or (more hoping) Frog Fractions from what I heard from other people. But alas it doesn't. If it does, however, devolve into an exciting madness, I did not get that impression during my time playing.As a side note: It would have been nice to remember your username each time you played through but this is just nitpicking.Anyway, maybe I'm wrong about the whole thing and everything I said actually exists and things get crazy and engaging or even quite long. But it never seems to, and it never did.It's a shame really, I hope someone does revisit this type of game again and really make it into something odd, slick and compelling.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												What a waste of time this was.If you like my went into this thinking "Hey, an otome game where you date birds? That's gonna be interesting." Don't. It is not. Under thin layer of novelity lays a rather dull game with a lot of problems. It's not bad enough for me to drop it outright, but it just gives you expectections and never delivers.At the start game takes a pity on you by giving you an option to show you a human version of a bird when you're first introduced to them. It's like developers new people wouldn't be able to relate to expressionless birds so they gave you a glimpse at what anime cliché they were going for. And yes, birds have no expressions. It's always one picture of a bird unchanging. Everything is expressed through a dialogue.Story feels flat. Sure at a first some events may seem interesting but then you realize that all of them are based on cheap tricks to induce emotional response. All of these events are not properly explored. After a while I just felt indifferent. It doesn't help that to get to the true-true ending you have to play it like 13 times? Half of those endings differ only by the fact that there is a few additional scenes. It's like reading a book with last page missing. You're like "that's it?", and then someone gives you that last page and you're just left disappointed.You can't even save to see branched paths because they don't branch. Most of those "missing page" endings are based on your stats. In order to see them you have to play the whole thing again, choose the same options but rise different stat durring classes.True-true ending has a terrible pacing. Story drags on and on breaking suspension of disbelief every time it speeds up a little. And even if you unlock everything to get the epilog you're left with a huge gaping plot hole and ending that's basically a cliffhanger which explains nothing.Music is just bad. It's just a handful of generic elevator music tracks. After my 10th playthrough it was just driving me mad. It made me actually glad for these few moments where there was no music.As for technical aspect, it's terrible. A lot of features you'd expect from a visual novel are missing. There is no history log and there is no skipping of read text, you can only skip on scene by scene basis. This combined with a fact that a lot of things happen in a common path makes it really easy to miss text. There is no way to tell at the beginning of a scene if you've seen it already or is it a variant of the scene with some events added to it. It's also far from bug free. More often than not, clicking on choices not register properly and you have to wiggle mouse pointer around for it to start working. Saving in some cases can also produce a save point that freezes a game when loaded from main menu (you have to load from a working save as a workaround and even then it sometimes doesn't work). Sometimes I wasn't even able to exit from save menu. And on top of that text not always fits on a screen.Overall do I recommend this? No. After novelty wears off all you're left with is a very short, hollow, buggy VN with a lot of grinding. I almost want to spoil it to you (which wouldn't be hard as there is not much to spoil) so you wouldn't have to play it.
